I was called up about one o'clock in the morning of 23rd Oct., to execute the search-warrant—I accompanied Mr. Marshall to Simon's house—Mr. Marshall told him that he was in search of hair trunk—Simons told me to take candles and light Mr. Marshall, and whatever property of his we found he was to take—he did not say whether he had the hair trunk or not—I took a light, we searched, and found some lace and other things, which Mr. Marshall claimed—I afterwards found the hair trunk—Simons gave it to me in the homestead—he took me there—it was in the open air that he gave it to me—he left me in the home-stead while he went and fetched it—he was not gone more than five minutes—I lost sight of him for that time—he went in the direction of a barn which is near a hedge, the hedge is on the right side—he came in a direction from the barn, carrying the hair trunk—I saw Mr. Marshall again about nine o'clock the same morning and went with him from the Magistrate to Simons's house, and there received possession of the oak chest now produced—I found it in Miss Simon's barn, upon some straw—Simons told me where to fetch it from—I cannot say how far the barn is from the house—it did not take me more than two minutes to go and fetch it—the barn belongs to the Misses Simons, two sisters of his—they do not live with him, but at another house, on the other side of the road—the barn is attached to the sisters' house—the chest was against the wall, upon some straw, five or six feet from the

ground—there was some loose straw about it, but I could see the chest, and the man that was with me saw it, and helped me carry it—the straw was packed—the chief part of it was in battens—the chest was in about the middle of the straw—we had to get up on the straw to get hold of it—it was about six feet within the outside of the straw—that was the same barn from which I had seen him bring the hair trunk—when I went to look for the oak chest the straw appeared to have been disturbed—there was some loose straw about—I have known Simons as a neighbour.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. You are not a constable? A. No, my brother is the constable, but he was not at home, and I was sworn in to execute the search-warrant—I did not take Simons into custody—the Magistrate told me afterwards not to let him go—that was no the second occasion—it was before that that I had declined to take him into custody—I have known him ever since I can recollect—he has always borne a most ex
cellent character in our neighbourhood—I never heard anything but the atmost honesty of him—he has lived within a mile of there all his life—he formerly had a farm there, and now keeps a licensed public-house—he has eight or nine children.
MR. BODKIN. Q. How many of them are at homewith him? A. Two boys and a girl.

(MR. HUDDLESTON here called upon the prosecutors to elect upon which act of larceny they would proceed, it being clear that all the property could not have been taken at one time. MR. BODKIN replied, that if called upon to elect at all, it could not be until the close of the case. The COURT was of opinion, that, although the articles ultimately found in the hair trunk might have been separately taken by the servant, yet that by their remaining on the premises they reverted onto the possession of the master, and that the removal of the trunk af
terwards was one act of larceny of all its contents.)

DAVID EVANS. I am a porter, in the employment of Messrs. Marshall and Stinton. I carried the hair trunk produced, from my master's premises to Madame Devy's 73, Lower Grosvenor-street, by Miss Simons's order—it is more than four months ago I think—I delivered it to the hall-porter there, and saw him give it to Ellen Simons, the prisoner's sister, who lived there—when Miss Simons gave me the trunk, she told me to take it down, and be sure to see her sister, and give her the trunk, and I did so—I corded the trunk at Mr. Marshall's—Miss Simons told me to do so.

ELLEN SIMONS. I am the daughter of the male prisoner, and the sister of the female. In July last I was living at Madame Devy's, in Grosvenor-street—in the middle of July last I received this hair trunk from Evans—in consequence of a communication that he made to me from my sister, I took the trunk to my father's house at Gumley—I did not receive the key with it—I cannot say whether my father was at home when I arrived—I did not see him directly I got into the house—I saw him during the time I was there—the trunk was deposited at his house—I could not say which room I left it in, because it was removed into two rooms during the time I was at home—when I first went, it was taken into my bed-room—I staid at home a month—I do not think it was in my bed-room when I came away—I took off the cord myself, at my own instiga
tion; I do not know why, I did not want it—the box was locked—I did not open it—I saw the oak-chest there—it was standing in the bed-room in which I slept part of the time—my mother was not well, and I slept with her during that time—the chest was in her room—my father and mother gene
rally slept together—about three months ago, after my return from Gumley,

my sister Ann handed me a key, at Mr. Hickman's—I believe it was the k✗ of the oak-chest—I was to keep it—she gave it me to take care of—she gave me not reason why—I had seen the oak-chest at my father's, and I knew that my sister had possession of it—it was in my father's bed-room—when she gave me the key, she said, "You will take this key, and take care of it for me"—I knew what key it was—she gave me no reason why I was to take care of it—she said it was the key of her box at home—she did not tall me what was in the box—I kept the key for about two months, until I knew my sister was in custody—that was on Tuesday evening, the 19th—I sent for my brother Nicholas, I think, on the Thursday evening, about seven of eight, and delivered the key to him—no one had told me to do so—I told him to take it to my father's, and also to tell him how ill my sister Elizabeth was; that I did not suppose she would live the night through—I also told him to say my sister was in custody—I did not say what for—to the best of my recollection this is the key (looking at it.)

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. You knew that the oak-chest was in your sister's possession? A. I did; I had never seen her open it—she told me it was in her possession, and she had the key of it—I went into the country in July, and stayed till Aug.—my father has been a farmer for a considerable time—he is not a man that troubles himself at all about domestic matters—he is a great deal more versed in out-door affairs than matters in the house—he does not occupy any land at present—he does not at all inter
fare about the state of the drawers, or anything of that kind—he does not even take his own things out of the drawers.

COURT. Q. Had any of the family been down to your father's from Christ
mas till you went? A. No; my sister Ann was down there last Christmas, and staid till a fortnight or ten days after Christmas—I went with her—the oak-chest was standing in my father's room then—I did not see that key in her possession at that time—the chest was locked—I tried it—I do not know why—I merely just lifted the lid to see whether it was quite fast—perhaps it was curiosity led me to do it—I knew that my sister kept things in it these—it was in July that I tried the lid, not at Christmas—I have seen my sister in the room where the chest was—I had not seen it open at any time.

NICHOLAS SIMONS. I am a son of the male prisoner. On the morning of 23rd Oct. last I received a key from my sister Ellen—I did not know who there my sister Ann was in custody then or not—Ellen told me to take the key down home, and give it to my father—I went down that same day, found my father at home, gave him the key, and said, "This is the key of one of Ann's boxes"—I did not tell him what had happened to my sister—I did not know that she was in custody at that time—I knew that she was charged with robbing Mr. Marshall, but I did not know that she was in custody—I told my father that.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. You mentioned to him what she was charged with? Q. Yes, I had heard that from my sister when she gave me the key—that was all that passed.
COURT. Q. did he say anything when you told him that? A. Nothing.

JOHN TADMAN (police-inspector C.) I received the male prisoner into custody at Market-Harborough, and brought him away from there in a fly—I was not in my uniform—after I had placed him in the fly, I told him that I was an inspector of police, from London, and that I had come down to take him for having received a quantity of silk, and other articles, which his daughter had been charged with stealing from her employers in town—he said, "Yes, I am aware of the charge against me, but I am as innocent as

You are of it"—shortly afterwards, he said, "It is a bed job for me that I should get into such a scrape from my children stealing from their employers in town"—I said, "Perhaps it is; the worst part of the charge against you is, that you removed, or caused to be removed, property, after your daughter was in custody in town"—he said, "That certainly is, but that was done through a communication I had from town, stating that my daughter was in trouble, and if the boxes were removed for a few days, all would be settled"—I then took a bundle from under the seat, and said, "I have been to Gumley to—day, and I have received this from your wife; she states that your daughter brought them down"—he said, "I have no doubt that is true, but I am as innocent as you of it"—that bundle contained the skirt of a dress, and other things, which the prosecutor identified, and which were found loose in various parts of the house—I have a list of the articles.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Did he not also say, "I don't think my poor wife knows anything more about it than I do?" A. Yes.

JOHN STINTON. I am in partnership more with Mr. Marshall, in this establish
ment, in Vere-street—there are servants of ours sleeping in the house—it is in the parish of St. Marylebone.

COURT. Q. Are there articles in that oak-chest, the value of which sepa
retely exceeds 5l.? A. Yes—I have not gone through them all—there ate some valued at nine guineas and fifteen guineas.

JAMES MARSHALL
re-examined. The value of the piece of handkerchiefs which the male prisoner asked me to give him, is a guineas and a half.
MR. SNELLGROVE. I am principal assistant to Messrs. Marshall and stinton, and have been so for the last seven years.

(MR. PRENDERGAST submitted that there was no evidence to go to the on the count charging the male prisoner as are accessory; it being accessory, in order to support that charge, that some act should be done personally to aid the principal felon: see The Queen v. Chapple, 9 Cur, and Payne, p. 355. MR. CLARKSON, with MR. BODKIN, argued that any act done with the stolen property tending to assist the principal in eluding justice was sufficient. The COURT was of opinion that, to substantiale the charge of being as accessory, some act of personally aiding and assisting the principal must be proved, and recom
mended the Jury to acquit the male prisoner open that count, unless they were satisfied that the oak chest was to his knowledge packed with the stolen property by the female prisoner upon her visit at Christmas.)
(Several witnesses deposed to Benjamin Simons' good character.)

ANN SIMONS—
GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.—

BENJAMIN SIMONS—
GUILTY., Aged 56.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prosecuter, or account of his age, and previous good character,—
Confined Eighteen Months.

div0.p: NEW COURT—Tuesday, Nov. 30th, 1847.

PRESENT—Mr. Ald. Wilson; Mr. Ald.
HUGHES HUGHES; and
EDWARD BULLOCK, Esq.

p.hi:
Before
Edward Bullock. Esq., and the Sixth Jury.

div1.p:
194.
JOHN CLOSTERMAN
, feloniously assaulting
Isaac Hughes, and stabbing, cutting, and wounding him, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

ISAAC HUGHES. I am a seaman, and lodge in Farmer-street, Shadwell. The prisoner lodged in the same house—on 29th Oct. he and I were out to
gether—we went to a public-house, and returned home—we were then good friends—on getting home he called me a b—y nanny-goat—(I am a Welsh
man)—I called him a b—y Dutchman—that was not said angrily—I after
wards got up to light my pipe—he caught hold of me by the throat, and I struck him—we had a fight—Thomas Jones was there, and he separated—the prisoner then went up stairs, and I went up in about ten minutes after
wards—Jones went with me—when I got on the landing-place the prisoner met me—I saw him directly I got up on the landing—I did not say anything to him, or he to me—he struck me, and some blows took place between us—Jones got between us, and the prisoner struck at me, over Jones' right shoulder—I do not know whether he had anything in his hand—I do not know whether he struck me more than once—I fell on my back on the stairs—I was cut on my nose and lip, and on my arm, just above the wrist—my flannel shirt was cut through—the wounds all bled—I cried, "Murder!"—the prisoner went down stairs—I was assisted down by Jones, and went with the policeman to the station—the doctor came to me, and dressed my wounds—Jones afterwards took me home—I went to the doctor's the next day, and came back—it was about ten minutes after the prisoner went up stairs, that I followed him—Jones was taking me up to bed—I had slept in the same room with the prisoner—I had only known him a few days—I did not strike him on the landing.
JURY. Q. Were you drunk? A. I was, and so was he.

THOMAS JONES. I am a seaman. The prosecutor has been living in the house where I do, and the prisoner also, for a few days—he and the prose
cutor came in on 29th Oct., between ten and eleven o'clock in the evening—they were both a little the worse for liquor, but not to say beastly drunk—the prisoner was not so drunk as not to know what he was about—they were sitting down, chaffing each other, and having words—I had occasion to go into the back yard, and there was no one in the room but the mistress—when I came in, the prisoner and the prosecutor were both stripped, and had a knock or two—the mistress told me to tell them to go out—I ordered them to go out and fight, or else not at all—they sat down, and still had words—the prisoner then got up, and went up two flights of stairs, and was there, I suppose, ten minutes or a quarter of an hour—the prosecutor then wanted to go to bed; and the mistress said, "No, sit down, and let the man get to sleep, and there will be no more quarrelling"—she took the prosecutor by the jacket—he got from her—she gave me the candle, and said, "Go up with him, or there will be more fighting"—I went up with him—I had the candle and candlestick in my left hand, and was pushing him up with my right hand—when we got up to the landing I saw the prisoner standing—words took place between them, but I did not take notice what—I tried to get them apart, and to shove the prosecutor along—I saw them strike at one another, but I cannot tell whether they hit one another—I kept breaking them off—I think the prisoner struck first, because I was shoving the prose
cutor along—he was highest up on the stairs—he was behind me, and struck over my right shoulder—I did not see any knife on the first or the second blow. but at the third blow I saw the knife in his hand—I saw the blood and I sang out, "Murder! murder!"—the prisoner was sober enough to run down stairs—I went down with the prosecutor, and the policeman was just come in—the prisoner was sitting down by the end of the table, and was going to

shut the knife—the policeman made him stand up, to search him, and a man said, "I saw something fall at his feet;" and the policeman picked up the knife at his feet—the prosecutor was taken to the station, and the doctor came to him—one of his wounds was near the end of his nose, one on his lip, and one on his arm—that was just cut through his clothes, but was not so severe as the wounds on the lip and the nose.

FREDERICK PICKERING (policeman, 87 K.) I was sent for, and saw the prisoner sitting in the mess-room—I searched him and beard some one call out that he had thrown a knife down—I saw him put his arm down—I searched and found this knife on the ground under his feet—there was wet blood on it.

DANIEL ROSS. I live in high-street, Shadwell, and am surgeon to the police. I saw the prosecutor on the night of the 29th Oct., at the station, bleeding profusely from an incised wound over the nose, which had nearly taken off the end of the nose—there were two wounds on the left side of the upper lip dividing the lip, and an incised wound on the left arm, which was not very deep—his flannel waistcoat had been divided with the incision—I dressed the wounds, and saw they were going on well—I think I saw him again two days afterwards—the wounds were healing then—this clasp-knife would have caused the wounds.

THOMAS JONES
re-examined. This is such a knife as sailors carry about them—some carry sharp-pointed, knives—they generally carry two or three, in case of losing them—a sailor might as well be without his jacket as with
out his knife—I know this knife well, it belonged to Strubin, who them lodged in the house, he is now sick in the Dreadnought—the prisoner borrowed the knife of him.

Prisoner's Defence. I and the prosecutor came home that evening—we were good friends—I was drunk—I sat down, and he began to call me names first—I would sit down and be quiet, and then he shoved me and I shoved him back, and he stood up and struck me in the face—I said I would have nothing to do with him, I would go up stairs—I went up and there was no light—I was coming down and this man came up, and he turned his face and said, "You Dutch b—r." and he struck me in the face—I do not know whether I struck him—I am very sorry for it—I was drunk at the time—I know no more than I heard in the station.

GUILTY of a Common Assault. Aged 25.—
Confined Twelve Months.

195.
JOHN ROBINSON
, stealing 1 1/2 bushel of oats, beans, and chaff, value 3s.: of
Thomas Grissell, his master.

HENRY ATTRIDE. I live in Edward-street, North-road, and am time-keeper to Mr. Thomas Grissell, a builder—the prisoner was his carman, and was employed in carrying coke from Vauxhall to Mr. Grissell's houses in Queen's-row, Bayswater—I was set to watch on Tuesday, 16th Nov., near the Swan public-house, in Bayswater-road—I saw the cart loaded with coke about two o'clock that day, and I saw the prisoner take a sack with about a bushel of something in it, from the front part of the cart—I told Mr. Gam
mon what I had seen, and I wrote T. G. and a cross on some small bits of paper that evening, and gave them to Mr. Gammon on the following morning—on the Wednesday I again saw the prisoner take a sack from the cart just as before—he carried the sack on his back down by the side of the Swan leading to a livery yard—I afterwards saw him hand a sack of coke down to somebody else—he then removed on to Queen's-row, where the houses are

building—I had seen the prisoner start on the Wednesday morning—he took his cart and sacks, and I saw him put a sack up in the cart beside what was in it—I supposed it to be this mixed food—I saw him put on the horses nose-bags and feed them at the Swan—I had seen the nose-bags filled, before he left the stable, from the corn-bin—I went with the officer to the Swan, and searched the corn-bin in the livery stable—I found a small piece of paper—I gave it to the officer and told him to open it—he said there was T. G. and a cross on it—I said, "Let me look at it," and it was one which I had written on the Tuesday evening, and had given to Mr. Gammon on Wednes
day morning before the prisoner left.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALF. Q. What was in the corn-bin at the Swan? A. Chaff, split beans, and oats—it appeared to be clover chaff—I saw some loose meadow hay about—I did not see the contents of the which I saw handed down—I wrote nearly a hundred pieces of paper, which I gave to Mr. Gammon on Wednesday morning—I found only this one in the corn-bin at the Swan—I searched for nearly two hours—it was about half-past eight on Wednesday morning that the prisoner stopped and handed down this sack—I was eighty or ninety yards off—I do not know whether he saw me.

COURT. Q. You saw him take two sacks from the cart on that Wednes-day one full, and the other partly full? A. Yes—when I afterwards west into the coach-house, I saw some coke in sacks, and some shot down on the ground.

HENRY DOWSETT (policeman, D 181.) On Thursday morning, the 18th, I saw the prisoner come out of the Swan public-house—he got on the front of the cart, and banded a sack half full of something to a man named Brewer—he took it down the Swan Livery-yard—he returned, and then the prisoner handed a sack three parts fall down to Brewer—he took that down in the same direction—I went down the yard, and saw Brewer come out of the stable with an empty sack—he took it up the yard, and threw it on the cart—the prisoner was on the cart, and he then went on—I afterwards went with Attride and another officer to the coach-house, and found one sack full of coke, another sack three parts full, and about three or four sacks of coke had been shot down—the corn-bin was about half full of beans, oats, and out clover-chaff—there was about a bushel and a half—Attride gave me this small piece of paper—I was standing by the side of the bin, when he found it in a handful of corn, which he took up in his hand—I saw the prisoner about three hours after that, he was proceeding towards the gas-works with his cart—I told him that Mr. Grissell had received information that he was in the habit of leaving coke on his way to Bayswater, and he thought it was not correct, and I was instructed by Mr. Gammon to order him to proceed to the yard with his cart—he said, "Let us go to the Gas-works first"—I told him he had better go to the yard—he wished to go to the Gas-works to see if he had not paid for the coke—he said he had bought it—he went on to Mr. Grissell's, and I followed—I saw Mr. Gammon there, and I told him in the prisoner's presence that I had seen the prisoner that morning come out of the Swan, about half-past nine o'clock, and hand down two sacks, one half full, and the other three parts full of something, and they were carried down the Swan-yard, and in searching the corn-bin I found this paper—I took a sample of corn from the prosecutor's yard, to compare with that in the bin at the Swan—they corresponded, but they got mixed together by mistake at the police-office—they are not distinct now.

Cross-examined. Q. You saw a Mr. Franks there? A. Yes—he went with me into the coach-house, and pointed out the coke—he said the sack which was three parts full belonged to Brewer, and the rest belonged to him, and he had bought it of Robinson, and paid for it, who said he gave 1s. 3d. a sack for it at the Gas-works—I went to the Gas-works, and saw some men who said they recollected his taking one sack—I found that when a man goes there for orders, it is very common for people outside to add to their orders, and they recollected he had had on one occasion thirteen sacks instead of twelve, because they would not sell less than three sacks—I examined the corn-bin, I did not find any other piece of paper in it—there were more oats amongst the chaff in the bin than there were in the bulk at Mr. Grissell's—Brewer came in and claimed the coke in the sack—I saw the prisoner's horses fed from the nose-bags at the Swan in the morning—I did not see what he did with the nose-bags afterwards—I was down the yard at the time he took them from the horses—they generally leave what food remains in the nose-bag, and buckle it on the shafts—I never saw them empty out what remains in the bag, and re-fill it.

EDWIN BENJAMIN GAMMON. I am clerk to Mr. Thomas Grissell—the prisoner was in his employ as carman, to take things to the buildings—on Tuesday, 16th Nov., I received from Attride from fifty to a hundred small pieces of paper rolled up—this is one of them—it has T.G., and a cross on it, and is Attride's writing—I threw the pieces of paper in the corn
bin with the mixed food of oats, split beans, and clover-chaff—the beans were Egyptian beans, and from that bin I saw the prisoner fill his nose-bags, and then take about a bushel and a half in a sack—that was not regular—he should have gone to the man for that—he would have been allowed to have some for his horses during the day—I have seen the beans produced from the bin at the Swan—they were Egyptian beans—there was clover-chaff in that, and a small quantity of meadow-hay, but none in ours—when the officer brought the prisoner to me, he asked if I would allow him to remain at home that night—I told him I had no authority to do so, as he had been seen to leave his corn two days—he said he had left a little, but it should not occur again—I told him I was very sorry he had been so foolish, after being with us so many years.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you been asking him about his leaving coke? A. I think I also told him he had left coke, and had left his corn two days, and then he said he had left some, or left a little—we do not allow our men to buy and sell coke, it would be contrary to our orders—we allow the prisoner and other men to take home a sack or two in their cart when they have done work—I put the papers in the bin about a quarter past six o'clock in the morning, and about half-past six the corn was taken out—I saw the prisoner return home on Wednesday—nothing had been said to him when he went out on Thursday—he had brought home some feed on Thursday, but none on Tuesday or Wednesday.

196.
CHARLES DOWLING and
EDWARD SHENTON
, unlawfully attempting to commit b----y.

197.
DAVID GOODERE
, unlawfully obtaining by false pretences, 2s. the moneys of
James Squires.
JAMES SQUIRES. I am a tailor, in High-street, Camden-town—I have

known the defendant about two years—when I first knew him he was clerk to Mr. Pellem, a solicitor, in Piccadilly—he came to me about three months ago, and said he had left Mr. Pellem, and was living with Mr. George, a solicitor, and that he himself recovered debts in the New County Courts, and Mr. George had granted him letters to enable him to sue persons in the County Courts, for unless a clerk had a lawyer's letter, he could not appear there—I employed him to get some debts for me—he was to take out a summons against Mr. Purvis, who owed me 2l. 14s. 6d.—I gave him 5s. 3d. to take out the summons in the Bloomsburry Court—I saw him a few days afterwards—he told me he had taken that summons out, and it would be heard on 29th Sept.—on 1st Oct. I received this letter from him by post—I know it to be his hand-writing—I saw him next evening, he told me the cause came on on the 29th, that he had attended, that the cause was un
defended, and the Court granted Mr. Purvis six weeks to pay the debt in—he said the money was to be paid into Court, and he had paid the ex
penses of the hearing himself, which was 5s. or 6s.—he asked me if I would pay him that, or give him some money—I gave him 2s. on account—I gave him that 2s. on the faith that the cause had been heard, and that he had paid the money out of his pocket—this was on 2nd Oct.—I have never received the money from Mr. Purvis, or the prisoner—I saw the prisoner again about three weeks afterwards, at the latter end of Oct., in Albary-street, and gave him into custody—he said he did not think I should have been so hard with him. that I should give him time—he said he was coming into some money, and he would pay it.

Cross-examination by MR. PARRY. Q. He was rather surprised when you gave him into custody? A. He was very much agitated—I did not give him a list of debts to collect—I gave him the names of three persons to take out summonses for—if he had brought me the money the next morning I should not have been angry with him, but he had no business to have gone to the parties at all—all I wanted was to get my debts in in the most expe
ditious way—this conversation on 2nd Oct. was not about other cases—Car
ter's business had been settled before—his debt was to be paid into Court—I had given the defendant his commission on that—he was not entitled to any
thing on Purvis's debt till I had received it—he would then have been entitled to half-a-crown in the pound—I gave him the 2s. on the faith of his having paid for the hearing—he told me the cause had been heard—I said to him, "By your letter, I perceive Purvis's cause has been heard"—he told me it had—I said, "Did Purvis appear?"—he said, "Yes, the cause was not defended, all that he did was to ask for time, and the Court granted him six weeks to pay the money into Court"—I do not recollect anything else that he said—he had not paid for Knight's summons—he had the money.

MR. PARNELL. Q. Was he to get the money through the Court? A. Yes—he had no authority from me to go to any of the parties themselves—the 2s. I paid him was not for the commission—it was on account of the money that he said he had paid out of his pocket for the hearing—he said he had paid either 5s. or 6d.—he told me he was very badly off—I gave him 2s., and he was to have the rest when he brought the plaint note up.

JOHN PURVIS. I have not been summoned to the Bloomsbury County Court, at the suit of Mr. Squire—I know the prisoner by his calling on me—he never served me with a summons—I was not at the Bloomsbury Court on 29th Sept.—the Court never allowed me six weeks to pay.
DAVID HOBBS. I am plaint clerk at the Bloomsbury County Court
I have the books of the Court here—I have examined them—here is no plaint of Squire against Purvis—there has been no such plaint since the Court was opened.

GUILTY. Aged 31.—
Confined Six Months.
(There were three other indictments against the prisoner.)

198.
CHARLES HAYWOOD
, unlawfully assaulting
William Proctor on the High Seas, to which he pleaded

GUILTY.—
Confined Nine Months.

(
There was another indictment against the prisoner for making a revolt,
upon which Mr. Ballantine offered no evidence.)

div0.p: OLD COURT.—Wednesday, December 1st, 1847.

PRESENT—Mr. RECORDER and Mr. Ald.
HUGHES HUGHES.

p.hi: Before Mr. Recorder and the First Jury.

div1.p:
199.
HENRY GARDINER,
THOMAS HOLLIDAY,
JAMES LOUP , and
JOSEPH SEAGER , (indicted with
Herman Cusell, not in custody.)
for conspiring, with others, to defraud
Henry Trimby Gray, and other, of their goods.—Other COUNTS, for obtaining goods by false pretences.

SAMUEL STUCKLEY BENSON. I am a jeweller, in partnership with Mr. Thoms, at 43, Ludgate-hill. In Jan. last, the prisoners Gardiner and Holiday came to our shop—Holliday said he wished to look at a liqueur-frame and a cruet-frame, that he had a commission for Hamburgh, and if they suited him he would purchase them—he said they were to be sent to Theberton-street, Islington, to be enclosed with other things that were to be sent to Hamburgh—I showed him some articles, and he selected a plated liqueur and cruet-frame, worth 9l. 15s. the two—the two prisoners conferred together, and it seemed to me as though Holliday required the approbation of Gardiner before he concluded the purchase—he gave me this card—(read—"Thomas Holliday and Co., Commission and General Merchants, London, 6, Pinner's-hall, Old Broad-street")—I packed up the things, and sent them to Theberton-street, by Paton—next day Holliday called again alone, and said that he had a further commission for a gold-watch and gold-guard—he said that the gentle
man who was with him when he purchased the frames was connected with one of the wealthiest firms on the continent, and that the frames were for that firm, which was Schulkhauser, Brothers, and Co.—he showed me this card—(read—"Schulkhauser, Brothers, and Co., Merchants, London, 38, Moorgate-street")—he said that that firm owed him a large sum of money, and that if I would allow him to have the gold-watch and guard he would obtain a bill from that firm for the payment of it, including the payment for the frames purchased on the previous day—I said that would be a matter for consideration, in the first place I must make inquiries respecting this firm, which I did, and ascertained that that firm, as well as Holliday and Co., were swindlers—I think this was about 7th Jan.—Holliday came again on that day to inquire if I was satisfied—I said I had not been able to ascertain com
pletely, to my own satisfaction, who that firm was—the result was, that I did

not let him have the watch and guard, not being satisfied with the solvency of the firm—five or six days after, I made inquiries at Pinner's-hall and The
berton-street, for Holliday and Co., and found that they were gone from both places—I afterwards made inquiries after Schulkhauser and Co., and they were also gone—my attention was called some months afterwards to the ac
count in the papers of some persons who had been taken before the Lord Mayor, in consequence of which I went to Giltspur-street prison—I saw fifty prisoners there, and out of them I selected Gardiner and Holliday—I saw my cruet and liqueur-frame produced before the Lord Mayor, from Mr. Boyee's, the pawnbroker.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. I believe you had known Holliday before, and had dealings with him? A. I had known him before, and had one transaction with him—I had not written to Holliday to come and see these goods—I sent a circular round, on opening the shop, on 16th Oct., to persons that I had previously had transactions with, stating that I had com
menced business on Ludgate-hill—perhaps I might have sent one to Holli
day, I am not confident of it—I had never seen Gardiner before—he was there perhaps a quarter of an hour—Holliday took the principal part in the matter—I did not, on making inquiries at Pinner's-hall, find that Mr. Schulkhauser had lived there with Holliday—I never heard the name till I saw it on the card—mine is a double shop, and moderately deep—they were standing close to me, only on the other side of the counter, some feet within the shop—there was no one else in the shop—they stood in various parts—they stood together in one part conferring for three or four minutes, but not out of my sight—we have glass show-cases round the shop, and I walked round with them, showing them the things—I will not swear there were more than twenty prisoners at Giltspur-street, when I selected the prisoners, but I think there were—I think Gardiner was standing next to Holliday.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. I believe you had been shop
man to Mr. Jones, of Cheapside? A. Yes, Holliday purchased some tri
fling articles there, to the amount of 3l. or 4l.—the gold watch that he wanted might have been worth 20l.—I did not tell him, while at Mr. Jones's, that I knew he was a person fond of a bargain, and I should like to have his address—I had his address, because I perhaps might have sent some articles to him—I do not know that I sent him a circular—I might have done so, perhaps, to all my master's customers—I have never seen Mr. Schulkhauser that I know of—I cannot say whether I have seen Holliday with any other person than Gardiner—I do not think I have, but it is so long ago I cannot charge my memory—Holliday gave me his card while I was at Mr. Jones's, and said he did a good deal in the export trade, and he could do a good deal of business if it was made worth his while; and he said the same to me at Ludgate-hill—he did not tell me that he had a ship of his own—I never heard that he had—I cannot say how long it was before he came to me at Ludgate-hill that I had this conversation with him at Mr. Jones's—I think the address he then gave me was in Broad-street, not Pinner's-hall—it did not strike me as odd that he, having a place of business at Pinner's-hall, should order these things to be sent to Theberton-street to be packed—I did not know where Theberton-street was—he said he had to enclose them in a case with other goods.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Have you any doubt whatever of Gardiner and Hol
liday being the two persons that came to you? A. No—if I had any doubt I would give the prisoners the benefit of it.

DAVID PATON. I am porter to Messrs. Benton and Thoms. On 6th Jan. I took a liqueur and cruet-frame to No. 10, Theberton-street, Islington—a little girl opened the door, and I left the goods—two or three days after, I took the invoice of those goods to 6, Pinner's-hall, Old Broad-street, and found that Holliday and Co. had left—I saw a female, who keeps the chambers, and she told me so, and could not inform me where they were gone—on finding that, I went back to 10, Theberton-street—I saw a female there, who referred me to Cross-street, Islington—I do not know the number—I went there, but could not find them—I found the name of Holiday on the door.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Did you find that a Mr. Schulk
hauser had been living at Pinner's-ball? A. No.

CHARLES REEVE. I am a pawnbroker, at Chapel-street, Lisson-grove. In Jan. last, I was assistant to Mr. Boyce—on 19th Jan. Holliday pawned this liqueur-frame and cruet-frames there, for 2l. 5s. each, in the name of Smith—these two duplicates (looking at two produced by Kibblewhite, the officer) are what I gave him.

SAMUEL STUCKLEY BENSON
re-examined. These are the frames I sold to Gardiner and Holliday.

EBENEZER KIBBLEWHITE (City policeman, 645.) On 5th Sept. last, after the prisoners were taken into custody on this charge, I went and searched Gardiner's lodging, at 19, Mount-street, Charlton, near Woolwich—I there found seventeen duplicates and among them the two I have produced.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. When you took Gardiner into custody, I believe he at once gave you his address? A. Yes, and it was in consequence of that address that I went and found the duplicate—I did not break open his drawers—these duplicates were sealed in a piece of paper—I broke the seal.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Where was Gardiner when you took him? A. On the second-floor landing of 52, Lime-street, leading to Cusell's office.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Outside Cusell's door, do you mean? A. Outside his officer-door—I do not know that Cusell is very ill—I should like to know where he is—I have seen him a few times, but not very latterly—I had no warrant when I went to Gardiner's lodging—I did not break anything open—I carried off these papers and love-letters, and some documents belonging to an old lady—I acted under my own instructions in seizing them—I considered that I had a right to take them—Gardiner and Holliday had been apprehended at that time, not for a misdemeanour, but for obtaining goods under false pretences—I had received no instructions from a Magistrate to go into his room, or any written authority—I seized nothing else there but what I have produced—I took other things belonging to him at the office, 4. Pancras-lane, and on his person—I produce the books which I found at the office in Pancras-lane—I am not on intimate terms with the attorney in this case—I never knew him till this trial came on—he did not tell me to seize all Gardiner's papers, or to search his lodging—I said nothing to the attorney about going to the lodging, until after I had been—I did not pro
duce all these papers to the attorney, I took some of them to him—I believe I have read them all—I saw the landlady at Gardiner's lodging—she was in the room when I seized the papers.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Are those books which you found in Pancras-lane the books of the firm? A. I believe they are—there are also packets of letters, some of which are yet sealed—I selected these papers from different parts,
but have marked where each was found—I have been looking after Cusell, but have not been able to find him.
COURT (examining the books.) Q. Where these leaves cut out in this way when you found this book? A. Yes.

MARIA YOUNGS. I live at 19, Mount-street, Charlton, near Woolwich—Gardiner has lodged there since Aug., 1846—he occupied a back bed-room up stairs at 5s. a week—he has paid me part of the rent, but there is about 8l. in arrear—I saw the officer search his room and carry off the letters and papers—it was Gardiner's room.

MARY ANN GRAVES. I am in the service of Mr. Deputy Corney, who is the owner of Pinner's-hall. I am housekeeper there—I know Holliday, and knew a person named Schulkhauser—Holliday and Company occupied No. 6 as an office—I always understood that the "Company" was Schulkhauser—I have seen him with Holiday at the office—I am not certain whether I know Cusell—Holliday and Schulkhauser came about 23rd Nov., and stayed till nearly the middle of Jan.—I knew of their having gone, soon after they left—several persons called too inquire about them afterwards—they did not pay for the office—they engaged to pay 40l. a year for two offices—" Holiday and Co." was on the door—I have seen their cards—this is one of them—(looking at the one produced by Mr. Benson)—I have seen cards like that—I do not know where they went to after leaving the office—I cannot say that I know any of the prisoners perfectly but Holliday.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Schulkhauser was pretty fre
quently at Pinner's-ball till the middle of January, was he not? A. Yes, very frequently, with Holiday; pretty well every day—Schulkhauser was a rather tall and good-looking man.

COURT. Q. Did you see any of these books there at any time? A. No; I have seen so many similar books in the different counting-houses, that I cannot speak to their being there—I think Holliday and Company left about 7th or 8th Jan.

JOHN TAYLOR. I am a furniture warehouseman, at Claremont-house, Islington. In Dec. last, Holiday and a foreign gentleman called on me and gave me an order for furniture amounting to 91l. 10s.—it was to be sent to 10, Theberton-street—the goods were sent there—I afterwards saw Holliday and the same foreign gentleman, at Pinner's-ball, when I applied for a settle
ment of my account—Holiday was to pay 20l. down and give a bill of two months—I never got the money or the bill—I called several times for it—on one occasion, when I went after my money, I found some person, I do not know whether it was Mr. Peachey, of Bishopsgate-street, taking away a piano
forte from Theberton-street—from inquiries I made respecting that, I deter
mined to take my furniture away with me, and by receiving a note from Mr. Holliday, I did so.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON Q. When was it they called on you? A. In the latter part of Dec.—the goods were entered in the day-book on 1st Jan. in the present year—I received the whole of the goods back again.
(The defendants, Gardiner and Holliday, here pleaded Guilty to the Counts charging them with conspiracy.)

HENRY TRIMBEY GRAY. I am a rope and cord manufacturer, in the Com
mercial-road. About the latter end of May, Holiday and Gardiner gave me some orders—they represented themselves as general merchants—in the course of those transactions, I saw Seager, and made inquiries of him respecting the goods supplied to Gardiner and Holiday, to which he gave me answers—he

was acting as their clerk—at the latter end of May, I supplied Holliday and Gardiner with rope to the amount of 91l. 19s. 7d., to be shipped to the Cape of Good Hope—Seager was in the outer counting-house, at 4, Pancras-lane, when the order was given and Gardiner and Holliday were in the inner one—the goods were to be packed, and marked "H. & C." in a diamond, and a number—a part of the first parcel was sent, I think, on 1st June, to the Custom-house quay—the rest were sent on the 16th—they were to be paid for in three months' time, or sooner, on the arrival of a vessel connected, as I supposed, with Holliday—if the ship came earlier, I was to be paid; if not, I was too wait three months—while the order was being executed, I went from time to time to Pancras-lane—on the last of those occasions, 28th June, I had some conversation with Seager—he used to be in the outer office generally—I am not aware that he could there hear any conversation—I called several times before the 28th, but am not aware of having any parti
cular conversation with Seager about the order—I sent the shipping orders by man to deliver the rope with—I gave Seager the invoice of the first delivery of goods on 11th June, the day after they were delivered at the wharf—(notice to produce the invoice was admitted)—that invoice showed them to be goods entered to be shipped, by having on it the marks "H. C." and the diamond—that is the mode by which goods intended to be shipped are marked—when I took the invoice on the 11th, Seager said, "Very well," and told me to get the others as quickly as possible—I might have seen him again before the 28th, but only in the outer office, to ask him if Gradiner and Holliday were within, and to deliver the account of the second parcel—I delivered the invoice and general account—the invoice of the second parcel was made out in the same way as for shipping—I do not remember what Seager said about the second invoice—until the 28th, I thought the goods had been shipped for the Cape of Good Hope—I went, on the 28th, for a general settle
ment of the account, and saw Seager—he said Gardiner and Holiday had gone to the docks respecting some goods that there was a dispute about, and had left word that I was to draw a bill on them at three months, as arranged—I asked whether the goods there was a dispute about were mine, or whether my cordage was shipped—he said my cordage was shipped.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. I suppose each time you went you found Seager occupying the outer office? A. Yes, as a clerk, as I sup
posed—I considered him a clerk in every respect—the office was fitted out with samples of Colonial produce, and had the appearance of their carrying on the business they pretended—that deceived me—this was the first transaction I had with Gardiner and Holliday—I had had a transaction with Holliday tow or three years before, to the amount of about 50l.—that was properly settled, or I should not have trusted him again—he appeared respectable then, and dealt fairly—my opinion was that he was a respectable man, and I stated so—if a person had wanted to go into his service, and had asked me what sort of a cha
racter he bore, I should have said he was a respectable man—I saw Gardiner and Holliday after the morning of the 28th—they accepted the bill in my presence—to the best of my recollection, I did not see Holiday on 28th, till after I had seen Seager—I swear that, to the best of my belief—I did not see him to my knowledge that day till I met him—it was between the 16th and 28th that I had arranged for the bill to be given—I made a charge against Gardiner and Holliday before the bill became due, but it was not about the bill—it was on a subsequent transaction—I saw Seager several times on that other transaction—he was in the counting-house, in the same way—I

made no memorandum of what took place on 28th—I rely entirely on my memory—he distinctly told me my goods had been shipped—I have no doubt of it—I know nothing about the goods that Gardiner and Holliday had gone in the docks about—I was examined before the Lord Mayor first on 3rd Sept. I believe—Seager was not charged for some time after.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Where the books which have been produced, in the outer office in which Seager was? A. No; they were generally on the table in the inner office—I have seen Seager in the inner office when I have called—I had no opportunity of looking into the books, or seeing what the transaction were.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did you ever see Seager in the inner office except in the presence of Gardiner and Holliday? A. He was there when I drew this bill, and instructed me to draw it in the name of Gardiner and Holliday—bill-book and other books appeared to be then lying on the table, and letters and papers.

JOHN PEARCE. I am carman to Mr. Gray. On 11th June I took six packages, marked "H C" in a diamond, to the Custom-house Quay wharf—I took with me a delivery order, signed "Gardiner and Co."—on the 15th and 16th I delivered ten more at the same place—I gave those on the 11th to Mr. Brown.

JAMES BROWN. I am a clerk at the Custom-house Quay wharf—on the 11th of June I received from Pearce at the wharf six packets of cordage and a receiving order—(produced)—this is it—on 12th June I received this order for the delivery of those six packages, I can't say who brought it—they were delivered—the order was to deliver to Ward's lighterman.
GEORGE WILLIAMS. I am a clerk at the Custom-house Quay wharf—on 12th June six packages were delivered to Ward's lighterman, by this delivery order.

JOHN HOLDSWORTH. I am a waterman and lighterman in the employ of Mr. Ward—on 12th June I received these packages on board the lighter, took them to the Kent and Essex wharf, Bankside, and left them there—Seager ordered me to do it—he went with me in the lighter—I knew him before—he asked one of the clerks to allow him to leave them there till Mon
day, as that was Saturday.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How long have you been a lighterman? A. About 40 years, and am well known in the trade—I knew Seager ten or fifteen years ago, when he was a respectable tavern-keeper at Finchley—I have not seen him for the last two or three years, because he has been out of the way, apparently, to me—he appeared to me to be thrown out of business by the railway—all the time I knew him he bore a perfectly re
spectable character—I did not know where to find him—he did not desire me to conceal this transaction—he does not appear a person knowing much about shipping business.

COURT. Q. Was any reason assigned why the goods were removed there till the Monday? A. They were going to Paul's wharf, but on account of the tide I persuaded him to land them there, or they would have had to lay in the boat all Saturday and Sunday.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Do you know Mr. Booth's, in Watling-street? A. No—Paul's-wharf might be the nearest landing-place to Watling-street—my orders were to take them to Paul's wharf—I have known nothing of Seager's character of late years—I know nothing about his being in custody in the course of the present year—he would know that taking goods to Paul's wharf, was not the way to the Cape of Good Hope.

CHARLES THORNE. I am a clerk at the Kent and Essex wharf. On 12th June I received from Holdsworth and Seager six packages of rope, in the name of Seager—he signed my book, which I have here—nothing was said about any other person—I did not ask whose goods they were—the name of the person who deposits the goods is put in this first column—in this case it is the name of the person to whom the goods belong, which is the same thing—on the following Monday, about the middle of the day, he came again and had the goods away in Mr. Ayrst's cart—Davidson was the carman.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. He delivered the things tem
porarily at your wharf? A. Yes—we always have the signature of the party taking the goods away, as a receipt.

THOMAS DAVIDSON. I was a carman, in the employ of Mr. Ayrst. On 14th June last Seager came to my place in Thames-street to hire a cart—he went with me in the cart to the Kent-wharf, where several bales were put into the cart—I cannot say how many—he then took me to Mr. Booth's, the auctioneer's, in Watling-street—as we went along, and before we got there, he asked me to assist him in taking some of the wrappers off—they had marks on them—some of the wrappers were taken off, and we went on to Mr. Booth's—I left the goods there, but not the wrappers—I was not paid—Seager said that Mr. Ayrst was acquainted with the thing, and that would be quite sufficient—I came away from Booth's, leaving him there.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did he give you card? A. No—I did not see him give one to Mr. Ayrst—I saw no card—I went by Mr. Ayrst's direction—I did not see Gardiner and Holliday while going with the cart from the wharf—I did not see anybody speak to Seager, or see him speak to any one—I understood afterwards that whoever had given the order was a customer of my master's, because, when I asked him about the payment, he said Mr. Ayrst knew of it.

JURY to CHARLES THORNE. Q. Was anybody represented to you as the proprietor of the goods? A. Seager told me to put the goods in the name of Seager, and he gave a receipt in the name when he took them away—the signature indicates the ownership—they were left on Seager's account.

ROBERT BOOTH. I am an auctioneer. I have carried on business at Budge-row, City, about a year and a half—before that, I was three or four years in Ironmonger-lane—on 14th June Seager brought some rope to me in a cart—it was brought into my warehouse—I do not know whether there were any marks on it—I did not attend to it myself; my son looked at it—there were no covers—Seager wanted to know whether we would advance money on it—I said if it was for public auction we would—he said it would be for public auction—I asked what he was, where he lived, and what he dealt in—he said he dealt in such goods as I sold at my public sales—I told him it would be put in the next sale—he gave his name and address, and I entered it in this book, which he signed—(read—"Advanced to Joseph Seager, of 2, Triangle-terrace, Camberwell, on the following goods:—14 cwt. 1 qr. 16 lbs. of rope, 21l. to be paid off in seven days, or sold to pay commission and charges without reserve; signed, Joseph Seager"—I said, "What can you be to live in Camberwell? what can you deal in;"—he said, "Why, I deal in everything that you sell in your public sales"—he wanted to know how much a hundred weight I would give—I said I was not judge of new rope, I knew what value old rope would be—he said it cost him 46s. a cwt., and therefore I said to myself I did not think we could do much harm at 30s.—I said, "We will give you 30s. a

cwt., and that will be 21l."—I wrote him a check for 21l., and he signed his name at the back—I never saw him again for two months—the sale which I intended to put this rope in, did not come off, and I advertised a sale for the 5th Aug., and put it in my catalogue as advertised for public sale—on 4th Aug., the night before the sale, Seager came to me, and said he did not wish me to sell the goods in the next day's sale—I said, "Why, you have had my money, I must have the goods turned into money again, I have no reserve on it"—he said, "What shall I give you to pass them to-morrow? because I can sell the rope for more money than you will get in your sale"—I said, "Give me three sovereigns, and clear the rope in the same time the purchaser would, and I will give you the rope"—he said, "I cannot give you there sovereigns, I have only got 50s., but I will be sure to clear it as soon as a purchaser," which was on the Monday, three days after the sale—I found, from a person that had been to look at the rope, that I had advanced too much on it, or I should have charged him 5 per cent.—the sale was adver
tised in the ordinary way; it appeared in the paper for six days—it was a sale by order of the Admiralty—there were also merchants' goods, and this rope was inserted—there were about 300 catalogues circulated—on the day of sale, when I came to the rope, I passed it—Seager never came to clear it—I have never seen him since—the rope is now in my possession.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Have you told us all you know about it? A. Yes—I know a person named Rodel—he came with Seager—Rodel was not at my place when Seager came, he came with him—I saw them come in together, and spoke to them both—I had not seen Rodel before that day; I swear that—I had not seen him the day before, nor the at home, but my son said that Rodel had been there before, to know whether we would advance money on rope and put it in the sale, but I had not seen him—I said to my son, "What did you tell him?" and he said, "That if it was to be sold at our next sale, we should not object to it"—my son is not here—I have known Rodel about twenty-three or twenty-four years.

Q. Is he respectable man? A. I know nothing about his property or employment, or anything of the kind—I would not give him credit, because I have lost 40l. odd by him—I would take his rope—I do not know how he gets his living—I do not think he is a ropemaker—he was a Prussian bl✗ maker when I knew him—I do not know his residence—I have not seen him for I suppose eight or nine years—I never knew him to have a ware-house, except about twenty-three years ago—I never knew him to have any dealings with rope—I did not know how he got this rope, or anything at all about it—Rodel introduced Seager as the owner of it—Seager said so him
self—I do not believe Rodel said it—they came into my office together—it was Seager that spoke; Rodel introduced him—I do not recollect the con
versation—I do not know that Rodel made any observation about him—I will not swear he did not—I think he corroborated him as to its costing him 46s. a cwt, because they wanted me to advance more—I cannot tell which spoke first—Rodel did not mention the names of Gardiner and Holli
day—I never heard of such names till Aug., that again has relation to my son, I was not at home—I saw Holliday two months after this affair, with Seager—that was not at the time of the 3l. being spoken of—my son did not inform me that Gardiner and Holliday had been to him about that business—at the time the 50s. was spoken of I had not heard to Gardiner and Holliday—(referring to a memorandum) I find I must have seen Holliday on 3rd Aug.—never till then—he did not came about this rope, and did not say

a word about it—he had been to my warehouse on 3rd Aug., to know whether we could put some carpenter's tools in our next sale—he left a care with my son, which I have here with "carpenters' tools," written on it—when I came in, my son told me a gentleman had been wanting to borrow 100l. on carpenters' tools—they were sent that afternoon, and I advanced 40l. on them—you will find it entered here in my book, and signed by Holliday, who borrowed the money—when Seager spoke about the 50s. he did not say he was obliged to go back and get the money; he had it in his pocket, for he took the 50s. out.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. How much did you understand was the value of the rope? A. I have since understood it is not worth 26s. a cwt.

MR. BODKIN. Q. That is, to sell at public auction? A. Yes—I never had any intimation from Seager of any person being the owner of the rope but himself—when Holliday came, on 3rd Aug., he never intimated that he had anything to do with it.

COURT. Q. Where was the rope put? A. In my second-floor warehouse—Holliday came there the day the tools were fetched away, and the rope was then lying in the warehouse in his view, but he never referred to it.

JAMES BROWN
re-examined. On 15th June I received a receiving order with ten packages of rope from Mr. Pearce's man, at Custom House Quay—I subsequently received this order, signed "Gardiner and Co.," to deliver the packages to Cusell and Co.—on 23rd June this delivery order, signed Cusell and Co., was received at the quay, but not by me, I think it was by Mr. Williams.

GEORGE WILLIAMS
re-examined. These ten packages were delivered to Wellock on 23rd June.

ARTHUR WELLOCK. On 23rd June Cusell employed me to lighter ten packages or rope to Frost and Schroeder's, at Wapping—I afterwards called at Cusell's office, in Lime-street, and received the money for the job—Rolt was the waterman I engaged.
JOHN ROLT. On 23rd June I lightered ten packages of rope to Frost and Schroeder's, at Wapping, and landed them there.

WILLIAM NORMAN FROST. I am a ship-chandler, at Wapping. On 23rd June I saw Loup on St. Andrew's wharf, which is next door to our ware-house—he asked if I was a buyer of rope—I asked what rope it was—he said he could not tell me, but it was lying at Custom House Quay; and I might see it there—I accordingly went, and met him there—he said it was not his own, it belonged to some party in the City, he did not say who—he asked what I would give for it—he said he did not know the value of it—I said 36s. a cwt., which he agreed to—there were ten packages; they were in wrappers, and I believe were marked in a diamond—I asked if it was ware-house make—he said he did not know—before he accepted my offer, he went away to consult some one, and then returned back to me, and said I should have it—he was not gone a minute, he just went outside the dock—I did not see him speak to anybody—after purchasing the rope, it was arranged to be lightered to my place, which was done immediately, on account of the tide serving—he followed the rope to my place, saw it landed and weighed, and received the money, 43l. 2s. 4d., which I paid him—he wrote this receipt in my presence—(read—"June 23rd; settled by cash, 43l. 2s. 4d. for H. Cusell and Co., J. LOUP")—I had never seen Cusell at that time, nor had I ever seen Loup before.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Had you been introduced to him by a gentleman named Reynolds? A. I had—he did not know anything about the quality or price of the rope—I had seen it when I offered the price for it—that was on the occasion when it was brought to my premises—my house adjoins St. Andrew's wharf—I have been in that business eighteen or nineteen years—I gave what I considered a fair price for the roe, and in
deed, I refused a third lot, not considering it worth the money I had given—as far as I was concerned, this was a perfectly straightforward, honest transaction.

MR. BODKIN. Q. I believe the value of rope depends very much upon the confidence you can place in the maker of it? A. Yes; I said 36s. was a fair price, because I did not know the maker of it—Loup said he did not know the maker—that lessens the price until it is tested—I have since tested this rope, and consider it 35 per cent. below that which we sell—Lodge Brothers and Co. make our rope—that is 35 per cent. stronger, and was sold at 44s. per cwt. at that time—it is difficult to tell what description of hemp this is made of, I should say the inside is little more than the bandages of bales of hemp—it is doubtful whether it is Petersburgh hemp, but it is im
possible to say.

WILLIAM JAMES BOND. I am a tool-maker, at King David-lane, Shad
well—in May last Holliday applied to me to sell him and Gardiner a chest of tools for shipping—I supplied him with some to the amount of 15l.—on 19th June I called at the counting-house for my money, and saw Gardiner and Holliday—Seager was in the outer office—I merely asked him as I went in if Gardiner and Holliday were in, and he said yes—I did not tell him what I had come for—Holliday first of all put off the payment of my money, and then introduced me to Gardiner, as his partner—they told me they had a shipping order for Sidney, for some tools, and would I supply them at the annexed prices, showing me a list—I subsequently received this letter from them containing an order for 150l. worth of goods—I went to the office to speak to them about it, and saw Gardiner and Holliday—I am not certain whether I saw Seager on that occasion—they told me that they had this order, and asked if I would supply them, giving them three months' credit—I said, yes I could, if they would give me a good reference—they said they would think about that, and I was to call again on the following Satur
day, the 26th, which I did—I then saw Gardiner and Holliday—they said they would rather pay me cash, and that would obviate the necessity of giving any reference, as they did not want other houses to know what busi
ness they were doing—it was arranged that I was to supply them with the goods, and as soon as they were ready they were to pay me for them—on 3rd July, I received another letter from them—the goods were ready about the 20th, and about the 28th I called on them with an invoice—I saw both Gardiner and Holliday—I am not certain whether I saw Seager—I saw him on several occasions when I went—I generally saw him—I have called when Gardiner and Holliday have not been at home, and have frequently left messages with Seager—on one occasion, after the tools had been de
livered, I asked Seager whether they had been shipped, and he said they had—that was a few days previous to my having the goods back, about the 1st or 2nd Aug.—I had called on 28th July, and made an appointment for them to come and see the goods, and on 29th Holliday came to my house—he gave me a shipping order to deliver them at Custom-house quay wharf—they were packed up in two casks and one case, which Holliday told me were to

be marked "P" in a diamond, and numbered 1, 2, and 3—they were to be delivered on the Thursday—he told me to call at at their counting-house in Paneras-lane, on the following Saturday, for the money—he gave me a refer
ence to a Mr. Woolcombe, St. Michael's alley, Cornhill—I went there and made inquiries of him, and when I returned home I received a letter from Gardiner and Holliday—I delivered the goods on 30th at Custom-house-quay—on 31st July I went to their office, saw them, and asked for my money—they said they did not know that the goods had been delivered at Custom-house-quay, as I was rather later with them than they expected, and I had rather led them into a dilemma, by not letting them know they were there, and therefore they could not pay me on that occasion—I called several times afterwards for my money—on some of those occasions I saw Seager—it might have been four or five days after I had delivered the goods that Seager told me they had been shipped—Gardiner and Holliday were not present then—I tried for some time to get my money, and was ultimately obliged to get the assistance of my solicitor to go to them—I could not get my money or my goods—I afterwards ascertained that the goods had been removed from Custom-house-quay—I traced them to Johnson and Day's, the packers, in Eldon-street, Finsbury—I afterwards went with Mr. Crauch. my soli
citor, to Gardiner and Holliday's office, and then started to go to Cusell's office in Lime-street, my father-in-law, Mr. Tucker, having received an order in Cusell's name to inspect some tools—as we were going, we met Cusell—Mr. Crauch told him that we were going to his office about some tools which he was offering to sell—Cusell said, "What tools? What tools do you mean, I don't understand you?"—Mr. Crauch said, "Oh, you must know what I mean, it is about those tools which Gardiner and Holliday have got from this chest of mine Mr. Bond for shipping, and which they are now offering for sale"—Cusell stammered a bit, and then said, "What shall I do for my money?"—Mr. Crauch said, "We had nothing to do with his money," and asked what money he meant—he said money he had advanced on them—Mr. Crauch asked what he had advanced on them—he said he could not tell exactly—he admitted that he and his friend Mr. Loup had advanced 40l.—as near as I can recollect he gave us to understand that he had advanced 21l.., and Loup the other 21l.—Mr. Crauch, Cusell, and 1, then went together to Gardiner and Holliday's office—we saw Holli
day, who said Gardiner had gone to Ramsgate, to purchase a vessel—Cusell said he must be paid, and he went away to fetch his friend Loup—we were to wait till he came back with him—we waited about twenty minutes or half an hour, and finding he did not come back we went in search of him to Loup's office, in Aldermanbury—they were not there—we went back and found Loup and Cusell at Holliday's office, with Holliday—Gardiner was not there—Seager was in the outer office—Loup said that if the 21l. that he advanced was paid he had no objection to the goods being given up—Mr. Crauch had not mentioned to Loup the circumstances under which the goods had been obtained from me—a good deal was said—Mr. Crauch said in Loup's presence, that the goods had been obtained for shipping, and they were evidently trying to sell them for anything they would fetch, and if they were not given up, or the money paid, we should go before the Lord May or immediately—this was about 16th Aug.—it was then agreed that I should receive my tools back upon Gardiner and Holliday's paying Loup the 21l.—I subsequently got my goods back from Johnson and Day—I had to pay 2l. to get them back—I was some five days waiting before I could

get the order, but ultimately, after again threatening to go before the Lord Mayor, they gave me an order to get them back—we called at the office for it, and Seager gave it us—this now produced is it—it was written by Holliday and signed H. Cusell and Co.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKON. Q. Who were present on that occa
sion? A. Holliday, Cusell, Loup, Mr. Crauch, and myself.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. How long have you known Holiday? A. About three years—I then had one transaction with him—that was an honourable one—he was then in a respectable station, and the owner of a ship as I heard—I had heard nothing of him since.

GEORGE WILLIAMS
re-examined. On 30th July I received some tools at Custom-house-quay—about 3rd Aug. an order came for their removal, is consequence of which they were given to Mr. Needle's carman—I did not observe anybody besides the carman attending to the removal.
WILLIAM NEEDLE. I was employed to cart some tools from Custom-house-quay on 3rd Aug. by a stranger—it was neither of the prisoners—I did not go myself, I sent a man who was jobbing for me.

JOHN CATON. I am in Mr. Needle's employ. On 3rd Aug. I carted three packages of tools from Custom-house-quay to Mr. Booth's, in Budge-row—one of the gents went with me—I do not recollect which it was—I do not know his name—I saw him before the Lord Mayor—I cannot say that I see him here—he went in to Mr. Booth's—I had not known him before—he went to the quay with me, and saw the goods loaded, and then took me to Mr. Booth's.

ROBERT BOOTH
re-examined. Last Aug. Holliday came to my warehouse about some tools—they were brought by Holliday in two casks and a case, and I advanced him 40l. on them in two checks—on 10th Aug. Holliday and Cusell came, took away the tools, and paid me 2l. for warehouse-room—they were to have been sold by public auction, but they said they did not wish that as they could make a better price—Holliday repaid me the 40l.
GEORGE ROBERTS. On 10th Aug. I carted two casks and a case of tools from Mr. Booth's to Johnson and Day's, in Eldon-street—Cusell went with me.

JOHN JOHNSON. I am a packer, in partnership with Mr. Day, in Eldon-street, Finsbury-circus—I know Cusell—on 10th Aug. he came with a van of carpenters' tools and other ironmongery to our warehouse—they were brought loose, some in a crate and some in a hamper—they were all new—they were left with me I expect to be packed; he did not say what for, I did not ask—he said he wanted me to examine them that night, to see that they were right—we took and laid them out=they were to be sold—they were not offered to me—persons were to come and look at them—that is not part of my usual business—I did not advance anything on them—Cusell was no acquaintance of mine, further than coming backwards and forwards with other people for two and three years—I arranged to show these goods—they re
mained at my place till 21st Aug., spread out for inspection—the morning after they came a person called by appointment to see them, and several per
sons came to see them—not many, perhaps three or four—I know Loup—he came the same evening that Cusell brought the tools—he looked at them, and told us to take care of them and keep them dry, so that they should not get rusty, and he thought the best place for them would be up stairs—he brought a person next morning to examine them, at least I cannot say he brought him, they were there together—when he first came they were not ready, and we appointed for him to come when they would be ready—Loup

was then present, and he came afterwards while the party was there examin
ing them—my partners showed them—I considered Loup was there as the seller, as the person offering the goods for sale; I have known him some years—the tools were afterwards taken away, and I was paid 2l. for ware-house-room—I did not learn from Loup that he had made any advance on the goods, nor did I learn anything of the sort from Cusell—Cusell did not bring any one to look at that, except his son, who is seventeen or eigh
teen years old.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Whether Loup had advanced money on them or not, you did not know, but he was interested in their dis
position? A. Yes—I have known him about twenty-seven years—he was formerly principal clerk to Tail and Co., Manchester warehousemen, of 8, Old Jewry, for two, three, or four years, till Mr. Tail died—he was then in busi
ness for two or three years, in Cateaton-street—the firm was Loup, Godby, and Co.—they became bankrupts, or something of the sort, in 1840—he was afterwards in the house of Pearman and Co., of Glasgow, and managed a house of theirs at 8, Old Jewry, for about eighteen months, up to just before last March—I have known him down to the time of this change—I never knew or heard of his being charged with dishonesty—as far as I knew he bore a respectable, upright character—he has latterly been a commission-agent, selling for any persons who employed him—he was so up to the time of this charge.

FREDERICK TUCKER. I went to Loup and told him I had heard that he had some tools for sale—he went with me to Johnson and Day's, and I saw some tools there—I asked where he had got them from—he did not say, but said he merely had them for sale—I asked him once or twice where they came from, and he evaded giving an answer every time.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. I suppose by your knowing where to find him, you knew where he lived and carried on business? Q. Not be
fore that day—I was referred to him by a Mr. Buck, over the water—I am a tool-maker—Loup came and bought a few tools of me a week or so after this—he paid for them—it was a trifling transaction—I knew these tools to be my father's make directly I saw them, and they had my father's name on them—my father is a plane-maker—I went to look at them, understanding they were for sale—they were readily sold to me.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Where was it you had the conversation with him? A. Going from his house to Johnson and Day's—I did not tell him who I was—I did not ask him who was the maker of the tools.

CHARLES PROCTOR. I have been in Mr. Loup's employ as porter, on and off, for four or five months, for four or five days a week—he told me in Aug. he had some tools to sell, and said they were at Johnson and Day's—he wanted to know if I knew anybody who would purchase them—I was living in the Waterloo-road—I said there was a person named Buck living close by, and I would call and leave the invoice with him as I went home—he had given me an invoice, which I left at Mr. Bucks, at the corner of Oakley-street, Waterloo-road—I saw big son, and told him the tools were for sale, that was in pursuance of directions given me by Loup—I said I hoped he would come to look at them as soon as possible, as there was a Spanish gentleman about to look at them next day—next day I went to Aldermanbury, to Loup's office, saw him, and told him what had passed—I used to go there every day—I never saw the other defendants, except at the Mansion-house—Seager I never saw till yesterday.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Were you in the employ of Pear-man and Co., of London and Glasgow, at the time Loup was? A. Yes; the London establishment was given up about last March, and I quitted one week and Loup another—Loup then set up for himself, and I went into his employ—he had the conduct of the whole of Pearman's business in London—he was there about fourteen months—I never heard anything discreditable or dishonest of him—he told me where the tools were, and said if I knew anybody likely to buy them I might take him to see them.

COURT. Q. Do you know a person named Cusell? A. I do not know him, I have heard speak of him—I saw him in Loup's counting-house on the subject of the nails—I do not know what passed; I left the counting-house.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Were there two offices at Loup's? A. No; I occupied the same office as Mr. Loup—his books were generally in the desk—I have not seen them about—I never took the liberty of reading them—I have no notion what was un them—I saw a gentleman who said he was a native of Spain—Buck went with me to see the tools.
MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. You were not clerk to Loup? A. No, porter,

GEORGE BUCK. I am a tool-maker, in the Waterloo-road—in Aug. last Proctor came to me, said he was in Loup's employ, and gave me a list of tools—I have not got it—I went to Johnson and Day's to see them—I did not buy any of them—I did not see Loup, or the Spanish gentleman—I heard of him.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. I believe you are a brother of Mr. Buck, of Newgate-street? A. I am his son.

FREDERICK JOSEPH RUTLEDGE. I am a glove importer, in Addle-street, Wood-street. On 6th Aug. Holliday came to my place alone, and pur
chased gloves for shipping, which came to 32l. 4s.—I delivered them; and soon, afterwards, in consequence of something I heard, I had a commu
nication with Mr. Barnet, the buyer for Leaf's house—I went to Pancrass-lane, and saw Gardiner in the outer-room, and Seager and Holliday in the other—I said I called for the money for the goods; they said they could not give it me just then, if I would call in a day or two they would see what they could do—I called several times afterwards—Seager used to be in the outer office—I did not see Gardiner and Holliday have any conversation with him on the subject of their dealings—I found my goods at Mr. Barnet's three days after I had sold them.
COURT. Q. Did not you say, "You told me the good were for shipping, and I knew they are at Mr. Barnet's?" A. No.

ALFREAD BARNET. In Aug. last I was buyer to the house of Leaf and Co.—Cusell offered me some gloves for sales—I bought them at twenty-five per cent. below the price; his son, who is a lad, was with him—I made a communication to Mr. Rutledge.

HENRY TRIMBEY GRAY
re-examined. In July last I received a letter from Gardiner and Holliday—that was after the first transaction of 91l.—I called on them at the counting-house, and they gave me an order for goods to be sent to Hamburgh—they said they were shipping for Hamburgh, and the goods were wanted immediately—they ordered fifty-six coils of rope, which came to 197l. 3s. 1d.—on 4th Aug. I sent ten packages to Custom-house wharf, and fourteen on 10th; twenty on 20th, and twelve on 24th, to Fresh-wharf; and on the following Saturday I called for the

money—I saw Seager in the outer office—when I saw him he was always acting as clerk—he made out ship's manifests, and lists of goods for exportation, as if they were large commercial people—he did not take any share in the discussions—I saw Holliday, and asked him for the money—he said his partner had not yet arrived from Harwich, where he had 800l. in his pocket, for the purpose of buying a ship—he offered me a bill, and left one with me—in consequence of information, I afterwards went to a public-house, and found Holliday—Mr. Barber accompanied me—while I was speaking to Holliday, I heard Mr. Barber ask Holliday if he knew Cusell—he said he had no knowledge of him; but soon after he was gone, he said he recollected him—I afterwards took Holliday in charge—he said the man that had left was the rogue, and his partner and he were the dupes—I afterwards went to Cusell's office—we waited on the stairs before we went in—Gardiner came up the stairs—4l. odd was found in his pocket at the station—the rope was worth 48s. per cwt.—there was nothing inferior in it, either out or inside—it was the best Petersburgh.
