Cross-examined by MR. BALANTINE. Q. I suppose hemp of other kinds might be of that value? A. Yes—my foreman who made it is in court—I charged the market price—it was 2s. extra, in consequence of the advance in hemp—Seager brought the current lists into the inner office, to induce Gardiner and Holliday to give me the 2s. a cwt. in advance on the second order.
JOHN PEARCE. On 4th Aug. I took ten packages to the Custom-house wharf; and on the 14th, ten; on 20th, twenty; and on 24th, twelve to Fresh wharf.

GEORGE WILLIAMS
re-examined. On 6th Aug., ten packages were taken from the Custom-house wharf by Fisher's lighter
THOMAS CLARK. I am export-clerk at the Custom-house quay. On 6th Aug., young Cusell brought an order for ten coils of rope—Fisher took them away.

JOSEPH FISHER. I am a lighterman. On 6th Aug. I received ten coils of rope at the Custom-house quay—they put on board my craft—a person representing himself as young Cusell gave me directions—they were to be taken to Frost and Scheider's, at Wapping—I did not see them afterwards—I made out a bill for my expenses, at his direction, to James Ellis and Co.

WILLIAM FROST
re-examined. On 6th Aug. I bought some rope of Cusell, at 36s. a cwt.—I paid him and his son.

JAMES ROBINS. I am a clerk at Fresh wharf. On 16th Aug. fourteen packages were delivered there—Mr. Glass, my fellow-clerk, received the delivery order, which was from Gardiner and Holliday to Cusell—I do not know where they went to—fourteen coils went on 20th, and twelve came in on 25th.

PETER GLASS. I am a clerk, at Fresh wharf. On 20th Aug. I received a delivery order for fourteen packages of rope from Gardiner and Holliday to Cusell—I afterwards received one signed Cusell, directing me to deliver them to the bearer—on 20th Aug., fourteen were removed—on 24th, twenty packages were delivered at Fresh Wharf, and I received an order for them from Gardiner and Holliday to Cusell—on 1st Sept. I received a delivery order from Gardiner and Holliday to a person named D'John, and another from D'John to bearer for the packages—I only know of one man who took them away, that was Hazell.
WILLIAM HAZELL. I am carman to Mr. Dale. On 1st Sept. I was with my cart on the stand, near the Monument—Loup came up, and asked

me to do a small job from Fresh wharf to the Leith and Glasgow wharf—I said I could—he asked what I should charge—I said I did not know—I went to Fresh wharf, and took twelve packages of rope—Loup was on the ✗ when it was loading—he desired me to go to the Leith and Glasgow wharf, and then went away—just before I came to the wharf, he met me at Mr. Duke's door, and said, "Turn the tail of the cart round, and put the coils of rope in here, at Mr. Duke's"—I did so—he paid me 4s. cart hire.
JOHN FRANKS. I am a carman. On 24th Aug. Loup employed me to take twenty coils of rope to Mr. Duke's, from Fresh wharf—he paid me.

RICHARD DUKE. I deal in rope sometimes. On 19th Aug. Loup's clerk came to me—I went to Loup's house—he told me he had some rope to sell, which was lying at Fresh wharf—I said I would go there with him, and see it—I went and saw it next morning, and offered him 34s. a cwt. for it—he did not state what price he wanted—he said, "If my principal will take it I will deliver it at your warehouse, and of course you will pay me the money"—I said, "Of-course I will"—I returned to the warehouse, and in the afternoon he brought the rope in a cart—there was 22 cwt. 2 qrs., 24lbs, less, 24lbs, short weight—it came to 38l. 5s.—after I paid him he said he had another small parcel would I take that—I said I had no objection—on 23rd Aug. I brought twenty more coils at 34s.—they came to 39l. 2s.—I paid him on 25th—he said he had a further small parcel, and on 1st Sept. I bought twelve coils, weighing 13 cwt, at 34s., which came to 22l.—I have not yet paid him for that—it was all new rope—I have sold it at 36s. and 38s. a cwt., subject to a discount—I have made ten per cent. on what I have sold—it was packed as for shipping when I saw it, with mats on it, marked with a diamond as stated in the invoice.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did he bring the invoice with it? A. We checked the weight at my counting-house, and he made this invoice out on my desk—(produced).

COURT. Q. Do things coming in mats, indicate that they are intended for shipping? A. No: he said he did not know whether it was London or country made; that it belonged to a friend of his who had advanced money on it—he did not mention his friend's name, till I made out the invoice—I produce the second and third invoices—they are made out for Cusell—I said at the time, "You do not make this out in your own name?"—he said, "No, for my principal"—I did not know Cusell till I saw him at the Mansion-house.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. How far are your premises from the Leith and Glas
gow wharf? A. Under fifty yards, just across the road. Q. So that if a man was directing another to go to your place, would not the Leith and Glasgow wharf be the very place to name? A. The best answer I can make, is, that in my own bill-heads I used to say, "Opposite the Leith and Glasgow wharf."

EBENEZER KIPPLEWHITE
re-examined. I served Loup with a summons to attend the Court as a witness in Mr. Gray's case, and asked him if it was likely Mr. Cusell was in, as I was anxious to see him—he said, "I know very little about Mr. Cusell; and as for Gardiner and Holliday, I know no
thing of them"—he said it was the first transaction he had with Cusell—that was with reference to the second lot of rope from Mr. Gray—I had not heard of the tools then, and knew nothing about Mr. Gray's first case, or of Bond's—I took Seager into custody—he said he fetched the rope from the wharf, on an order, signed "Gardiner and Holliday," and took it to west Kent wharf, and fetched it from there two days afterwards, with a horse and cart; left it at Mr. Booth's and got 21l.—he did not say anything about

taking the covers off—next day, in conveying him from the station to the Mansion-house, he said, "Have you found all the books in Gardiner and Holliday's office?"—I said, "we have found all that we can find—he said, "I don't think you have got all;" and then said, "If you go and look into the further cupboard, in the inner office, you will find it propped up against the front of the cupboard; you can't see it, you must put your hand in"—I went there, and found this book—it is one of those I have produced.

COURT to MR. DUKE. Q. Seager represented himself to you not as the owner, but that he had a principal; are such transaction common in trade? A. Very common—I understood he was the agent—there are jobbers who sell articles which are not shipped—they are called general agents—I have had about thirty tons of rope before under similar circumstances—if a party ordered the rope, and it did not answer, when delivered, that would be a fair reason for returning it—I think this rope was made in the country, and afterwards sent to London for sale—the marks do not indicate foreign ship
ments, as a matter of course—I believe they were country goods sent to town, and sold in town—coasters discharge their cargo at that wharf—it is not a place necessarily implying that goods are going outwards—we make a mark on the goods, which we know them by; we do not choose the world to know who our correspondents are—the address is not put on goods at the wharf.

MR. BALLANTINE to EBENEZER KIPPLEWHITE. Q. When you took Seager into custody did you tell him it was for removing six packages from the Custom-house, taking then in a cart to Budge-row, getting 21l., and signing Mr. Booth's book in his own name? A. I told him that was the charge—I will not be certain that I said he paid Mr. Booth 50s. on 4th Aug. for back
ing the goods—it is very likely I may have said, "We have proof that you have taken the gunny-bags having the shipping-mark on them off the rope, and then taken the covers away with you"—I cannot say positively that I said so—I recollect the substance of what passed; very likely that was part of it, I am not certain—he said he took them to West Kent wharf, in a boat, and that it was his intention to have taken them to Paul's-wharf, and that Holliday was to meet him there—I do not recollect his telling me that the waterman would not let him go so far on account of the tide running so strong, and at the suggestion of the waterman, he left them at the West Kent wharf—the waterman told me that—Seager acknowledged it at the Mansion-house—he said, that on the 14th he fetched them in the cart, and took them to Mr. Booth, and got 21l. on them from Mr. Booth, and told Mr. Booth they were from Gardiner and Holliday—I swear he did not say to me that Mr. Booth said he only knew him, Seager, in the matter—Mr. Booth said so at the Mansion-house.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Was Loup examined as a witness before the Magi
strate? A. I think he was on the first summons—(The deposition of Loup was here read by MR. CLARKSON by MR. BODKIN'S permission—"I am a Commission Agent, at 32, Aldermanbury; I do not know the prisoners; I know Mr. Cusell; I sold some goods for him; some coils of rope in Aug. last; I sold some of them to Mr. Duke for 34s. 8d. per cwt., and sold some for him to Messrs. Erost and Schieder in the month of June."
Seager. I know nothing of the tools, I was away at the time; it was represented to me that the tools were shipped.
----RICHMOND. I am a livery stable-keeper, at Broadway, Ludgate-hill—I have known Gardiner forty years—he is an honest man.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN Q. Do you know of his being in custody during the present year? A. Never until the last two days—I have know him down to the present time—such a thing may have occurred without my knowing it

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Could he have been imprisoned or convicted with
out your knowing it? A. I should think not—I adhere to my opinion that he is an honest, respectable man
(Several other witnesses deposed to the characters of Gardiner, Holliday, and Loup.)

GARDINER—
GUILTY. Aged 31.

HOLLIDAY—
GUILTY. Aged 23.

SEAGER—
GUILTY of Conspiracy.

LOUP—
NOT GUILTY.
(The amount of property fraudulently obtained was stated to be above 500l.)

div0.p: ESSEX CASES.

div1.p:
200.
DAVID ADAMS
, feloniously assaulting
Maria Cressy, and cutting and wounding her on the neck and throat, with intent to murder her—2nd COUNTS, with intent to do her some grievous bodily harm.—Two other COUNTS, stating her name to be
Maria Challis.

MSRIA CRESSY. I live at Chapel-end, Walthamstow—I formerly lived with Henry Challis, and had six children by him—he died last May twelve month—the prisoner lodged in my house from 16th May last—he left on Friday evening, 29th Oct., on account of a quarrel which took place that evening between us—he had proposed marriage to me several times—he come home as usual that evening, about six o'clock, very much in liquor, and began to use very ill language, saying there was neither tea nor anything ready for him—that caused the words—he stopped at home about an hour, but had no tea—I locked him out on account of his language—on Sunday night, 31st Oct., I went to bed about a quarter before twelve—had not seen the prisoner between the Friday and the Sunday—my daughter and two of the children went to bed with me—my mother slept in the same room, but not in the same bed—I was awoke between five and six by a board falling on the foot of the bed, where my little boy lay—myself and two children were at the top—the little boy cried, and my daughter rose up in bed bad spoke to him, but I did not—I felt something the matter with my throat, and I said I thought my child had scratched me—my night-gown was very wet with blood—one of my little boys brought a light, and I found myself swimming with blood—I found my throat had been cut, and the blood was streaming with wound—I saw my mother pick up a handkerchief by my bedside—I had seen a handkerchief like that round the prisoner's neck on the Friday evening—there was no mark on it that I can swear to it by, only by the colour and pattern—I have washed one like it a dozen times or more—washed for the prisoner every week—the handkerchief was not in the room when I went to bed—Mr. Brown, the surgeon, attended me.
ELIZA CHALLIS. I am the prosecutrix's daughter, and live with her. On

the Sunday night I went to bed with her in the same bed—I was awoke in the morning, between five or six, by a board falling at the foot of the bed, and my little brother crying—one of my brothers afterwards lighted a candle, and I saw my mother's throat was cut, and her night-gown all bloody—I saw the neck-handkerchief after it was picked up by my grandmother—it was the same pattern as the prisoner's handkerchief—on my solemn oath the hand
kerchief was not in the room when I went to bed—I saw the prisoner wear
ing that handkerchief on the Saturday morning, when he came to the window for his victuals—he was refused admittance, the door was locked.

COURT. Q. I suppose you cannot speak to the identify of the handker
chief, farther than saying it was the same pattern? A. No.

SOPHIA CRESSY. I am the prosecutrix's mother, and live with her. The prisoner lodged at her house previous to 31st Oct.—for the last three months he has conversed with me respecting his marrying my daughter—I told him he had better not think anything of her, as she had a large family—he spoke of marrying her several times—I saw him on Friday, 29th Oct.—there was a quarrel about the tea not being ready when he came home in the evening—there were a great many words, and, being persuaded by the police, we turned him out of doors, and would not let him rest in the dwelling that night—on Saturday morning he came to the window, and asked for his victuals—I gave him the box he had his victuals in, and he took what he had, out of the box at the window—I slept in my daughter's room on the Sunday night, and was awoke by the falling of a foot-board—I afterwards, when the light was brought, saw the state in which her throat was—I picked up a handker
chief which laid by the bedside, and laid it on the bed—I am sure that hand
kerchief was not in the room on the previous night—I have seen the prisoner wearing a handkerchief of the same colour as that, and have washed it several times while he lodged in the house—there is no particular mark about it—to the best of my knowledge it is the same—he had the same sort of handker
chief on Saturday morning—when I found the handkerchief, I had a strong suspicion, the instant I saw it, that it was the prisoner's—I was the first that went down stairs—I went to the back door—it was open, and there was a ladder placed, so that a person could get through the window of the room where the witness Howe used to sleep—the ladder belonged to Mr. Soames, a farmer, living near—I saw a pair of boots which were found in the privy—they were the prisoner's boots—a woman of the name of Adams showed them to me—they are the same that the policeman, James M'Colloch, has the custody of—I did not fasten up the house the night before.

JOSEPH HOWE. I am a labourer, and live in the prosecutrix's house. On the Sunday night I went to bed between eleven and twelve o'clock—my room window was fastened—one of the panes of glass had been broken, and a piece of paper fastened over it, to keep out the air—I awoke in the morning little before six—I saw the state the prosecutrix's throat was in—I was the first that went down stairs; and half-way down the stairs, nearly at the bottom, I found the top part of a razor-case—those were the stairs leading up to the room where the prosecutrix was—I found the other part of the razor-case in the back kitchen window—I had seen that razor-case in the house before—the prisoner used to use it—I have seen it in the house when he was there—it used to be kept on the back kitchen shelf—I went out at the back door; it was closed, but unfastened—I know it had been fastened the night before—it opened from within—I went outside, and saw a ladder placed at the right side of the window, by which a person could get into the

room I used to occupy—I went up the ladder—the window was closed, but not fastened—it had been fastened the previous night—I had worn a pair of boots on the Sunday, and afterwards put them in the kitchen, under a chair—I missed them—the policeman, Ward, afterwards showed them to me—I found the paper removed from the window—it had been safe the night before—a person from the outside could have put his hand through the place where the paper was, and open the window.

COURT. Q. Were you lodging there before the prisoner? A. Yes—nobody used this razor-case but him—I took notice of this end of it, so as to be able to identify it—I cannot say it is the same razor-case that he used, only that it is like it.
MR. COOK. Q. Did you describe to Ward the shoes you had lost before they were shown to you? A. Yes.

JAMES WARD (policeman, N 144.) I produce a pair of shoes which I get from the prisoner when he was in custody at Hford gaol—he was wearing them—I had previously, on that same day, received a description of a pair of shoes from Howe, which corresponded with these shoes—they are very remarkable—there are two rows of nails outside the heel, one row inside, one row round the sole, and a few knocked out of each row, besides a patch on the right shoe, where there are two holes—Howe told me of all this before, and, finding they corresponded with his description, I took possession of them.

HENRY WHALE (policeman, N 148.) On Tuesday, 2nd Nov., I saw the prisoner on the road to Chingford—I asked if he had heard about the woman that had had her throat cut at Chapel-end—he said he had—(I did not at that time know it was the prisoner)—I said, "I suppose, then, there is some truth in it—he said he did not know much about it, for he had only heard it himself—I asked where he lived—he said at Hale-end—I asked where he slept on the night of 1st Nov.—he said he had slept in the forest—I saw that he had his left hand in his pocket, and when it was taken out I saw that he had lost two fingers—upon that I said that he was the very man that was suspected to have done it—he did not say anything, but appeared very much agitated—I took him into custody—as we were going along he asked me if the woman's throat was cut very badly, and whether she was dead—I told him I did not know, I knew very little about it—he said, "Ah! I was drunk at the time"—as we were going along, my attention was called away from him, and he ran away—I overtook him—he had no neckerchief on when I took him.

COURT. Q. Had he when you first saw him? A. No—he had on a pair of blucher boots like those that were afterwards in Ward's possession—I can
not tell whether they were the same.

GEORGE HUNTER (policeman N 357.) On Monday, 1st Nov., I saw Mrs. Cressy—I afterwards searched round the premises, and in the privy of the adjoining yard found these boots, which I produce—there is a row of houses—the back premises of Mrs. Cressy are only separated from the adjoining yard by a small temporary wooden fence, which was broken down, so that anybody could get over—I saw footmarks leading from Mr. Soames' farm-yard, across a ploughed field, to the back of these yards—some of the foot-marks were perfect enough to enable me to notice the marks on them—after finding the boots I went with Serjeant M'Culloch to the field—I had not noticed the impressions at the time I found the boots, but about twenty minutes afterwards—the boots were out of my possession about five minutes—Sophia

Cressy had them to take into the house—she did not go with them to the field, to my knowledge—I saw M'Culloch put the boots into the impress
sions in the field—he put them down into the marks, and afterwards made an impression with them—I only saw him put them into one mark—there were impressions all across the field—he put the boots into more than one.

JAMES M'CULLOCH (police-sergeant N 36.) I compared these boots with the footmarks—I first made an impression alongside the other, and then com
pared them—they agreed—I did that in several places—I never put the boots into the mark—I could see the footsteps right across the field—they were all the same sort of footsteps—they were coming in a direction towards Mrs. Cressy's house—I showed those boots to Mrs. Cressy's mother.

SOPHIA CRESSY
re-examined. These are the prisoner's boots—I know them by the heels being broken out in several places, and by moving them about, the house from place to place when he has been gone to bed in the house—the policeman brought them to me before he took them to the field—I think I had them for an hour or two, but I cannot recollect—they were kept in the back kitchen during that time—I did not go with them to the field.

JOHN DALLISON BROWN. I am a surgeon, at Walthamstow. On 1st Nov. I was called to the prosecutrix—I found a wound on the left side of her throat extending about three inches—the wound generally was superficial, with the exception of one part, where I presume the instrument had pene
trated rather deeper through the muscles, and consequently had produced considerable hemorrhage—no doubt a sharp instrument such as a razor must have inflicted it—it was a clean cut—there was a considerable degree of ex
haustion from loss of blood, so much so that for several days I considered her life in danger—that was attributable to the loss of blood, and to her being in an impoverished state of constitution, being a pauper—the wound was over a vital part—it had commenced by the windpipe, and had passed over the carotid artery—if it had wounded her there, immediate death would have followed.

JAMES M'CULLOCH
re-examined. I found no footmarks leading from the house—the road comes close up to the house, and there would be no marks there—there were footmarks, but not similar to the prisoner's—there were some similar to Howe's shoes, but I could not tell exactly—they were not found until the 6th, and it was too late then to make any comparison.

JOSEPH HOWE
re-examined. The shoes produced are mine.
Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing of it; I am quite innocent.

GUILTY on 1st Count. Aged 38.—
DEATH recorded.

201.
ELIZABETH CONNOR
, stealing 21 boards, value 2s. 6d., and 21 pieces of wood, 2s. 6d. the goods of
Robert Curtis and another.

GEORGE DEANE. I am shopman to Robert Curtis and his partner. On 14th Nov., between nine and ten o'clock, I saw the prisoner leave the building with this wood in her lap—I followed her, and found it on her—it is my master's property—she had no business with it.
Prisoner's Defence. Hardship and misfortune drove me to it.

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 64.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.

div1.p:
202.
THOMAS JORDAN
, stealing 1 leathern girth, value 12s., the goods of
Philip Bailey.
PHILIP BAILEY. I had a leathern girdle at my house at Low Layton—it
was safe on the morning of 6th Nov., when it left my house—I missed it that evening—this is it—it is mine.
THOMAS PAVELY. I am servant to Mr. Bailey. On 16th Nov. I was going from London, and called at the Plough and Harrow between five and six o'clock—I missed my wanty—this is it.
ROBERT BAKER. The prisoner brought me this leathern girdle—I did not, buy it—I went to the ostler at the Plough and Harrow the next morning.
Prisoner. Q. Did I steal it? A. I do not know—you left it with me on Monday evening, 8th Nov.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought if for 4s. 6d. in Whitechapel.

GUILTY. Aged 47.—
Confined Two Months.

203.
HENRY KEYS
, 3 bushels of oats, peas, and chaff, value' 6s., the goods of
John Maxwell and another, his master; and
WILLIAM GRANBY
feloniously receiving the same.

JOHN MAXWELL. I live at East Ham, and am a farmer—Keys was my carman—it was his duty to feed my horses with a mixture of oats, chaff, and peas at home, and to take out three nose-bags full for his three horses—I have examined this mixture—(produced)—it is mine—Keys had no busi
ness with this quantity from my house.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALF. Q. How many days ought Keys is have been absent? A. He ought to have returned home by ten o'clock the same morning—he started at three o'clock in the morning, but he ought not to have started till five—my brother is in partnership with me—he gave out the corn in the evening to Keys.

JOSEPH BENTON (policeman, K 381.) On 2nd Nov. I was on duty by the Pigeons, in the Romford-road, about a mile from Mr. Maxwell's, and ✗ Keys drive the wagon into the Pigeons yard—it was drawn by three horses—Granby was standing by the tap-door—he and Keys had some conversation—they went into the house, and were there ten minutes, or a quarter of an hour—they came out, and conversed again for two or three minutes—Granby then took something from his pocket and gave it to Keys—they both went to the wagon—Keys got a sack off the fore-ladder, and Granby took it up—he saw me, and ran very fast into the public-house—I called him out, and told him I must take him into custody—the sack had chaff and peas in it—the prisoners asked me if I would look over it—I told them I could not.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. When did you first recollect that Granby took something out of his pocket? A. I stated it before the Magi
state—the deposition was read over to me—I did not notice whether that was in it or not—I have no doubt I stated it—I did see what Granby gave Keys—I was six or seven yards from him—I could see them take the sack off—persons feed their horses there when they come a long distance—I saw Granby go to the wagon, and Key handed him the sack—when Granby saw me he threw the sack down and ran into the house—I am sure he saw me—the Magistrate did not ask me that.

HENRY MILES (policeman, K 235.) I took Keys into custody—he told me he drew his horses up to the Pigeons to give them water and get a cup of coffee, and Granby came and asked him if he had got anything that morning for him—he said he had got but a little, and it was the first time he did any
thing of the kind.

204.
WILLIAM GILSON
, stealing 41lbs. weight of lead, value 5s., the goods of
Thomas Rogers, fixed to a building.

JOHN FLORES. I am watcham to Thomas Rogers, of Forest-gate, West Ham—he is building some houses there. On 2nd Nov. I went on to the roof and missed thirty-six inches of lead which had been fixed there—this lead (produced) is Mr. Rogers'—his initials are on it—it fits the place precisely—it is worth 5s.
RICHARD JAQUES (policeman.) I produce the lead—I the prisoner come out of a marine-store dealer's—I went in, and the party gave me the lead.
EDWARD GODFREY. I am a marine-store dealer. My wife bought this lead of the prisoner for 2s. 9d.—I was present—I never bought any before, and was not acquainted with the value of it.
Prisoner's Defence. A young man said if I would carry this piece of lead be would give me a pot of beer; he gave me 4d. I have not seen him since.

GUILTY.** Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

205.
GEORGE YOUNGE
, stealing 1 tame duck, price 2s., the goods of
James Cassels:—2nd COUNT, 1 dead duck.

GEORGE WYBROW. On 22nd Nov., about twelve o'clock, I saw the prisoner on the bridge at Wanstead, with another person—they had two dogs, which ran after some ducks—one dog caught a duck and killed it—the pri
soner picked it up and walked off with it—they wee tame ducks—I and Davis followed the prisoner, and took the duck from him, wrapped up in a coat—he did not say anything—he ran away—I afterwards showed the duck to Mrs. Cassels, and she knew it—she lives about 200 yards from where the duck was killed.

JAMES DAVIS. I pursued the prisoner—there was another man with him who escaped and gave the prisoner his coat—the prisoner carried it—I took it, and found a dead duck in the pocket—I showed it to Mrs. Cassels—she identified it.
HARRIET CASSELS. I am wife of James Cassels. I saw the duck—it was my husband's—it was quite dead—I had seen it alive about two hours before.
JAMES CASSELS. It is my duck.
JASPER SMITH (policeman.) About a quarter past twelve o'clock the prisoner was brought to me—I took him in charge, and told him what it was—he made no reply.
Prisoner's Defence. The duck was in a chap's pocket, who gave me his coat to hold while he went to make water; I did not know the duck was in the pocket; Mr. Davis took it from me.

GUILTY. Aged 18.—
Confined One Month.

div0.p: KENT CASES.

div1.p:
206.
WILLIAM JONES, alias John Coles
, uttering counterfeit coin after a previous conviction; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 25.—
Transported for Seven Years.

207.
THOMAS GRIFFIN
, stealing, on 19th Oct., at Greenwich, 1 watch value 6l. 1 watch-guard chain, 4l. 2 brooches, 5s. and 1 diamond ring, 2l. the goods of
James Buckland, in his dwelling-house.

JAMES BUCKLAND. I keep the Coach and Horses, at Greenwich. It is my dwelling-house—on 19th Oct., about eleven in the morning, I left in my bed-room, on the third floor, a watch, a chain, two brooches, and a ring—the watch and chain were on the mantel-piece, and the brooches and rings on the table—I left the door shut, but not locked—I went up again about five in the afternoon, and they were gone—about ten in the evening the witness, Evans, called on me and produced the watch and chain—this now produced is it—this gold brooch is also mine; it was given me by Mrs. Matthew—I know the prisoner by sight—I gave 12l. for the watch and chain, 2l. 10s. for the brooch, and 2l. for the ring.

JOHN EVANS. I live in East-lane, Greenwich. On 19th Oct., about a quarter-past seven in the evening, I saw the prisoner in Greenwich—I knew him before—he had a watch and chain round his neck—I afterwards went into the Red Lion public-house, and saw him there—I saw him give the watch to a young man named Fitzgerald, who gave it to a man named Daley to look at—I said I though I knew the owner of if—Daley, upon that, gave it to me, and I took it straight to Mr. Buckland.

REBECCA MATTHEWS. I am the wife of William Matthews. On 19th Oct., about five in the afternoon, the prisoner came to our house—I had seen him before—he had a guard round his neck, a watch in his bosom, a ring on his finger, and a brooch in his shirt—this is the brooch—he asked if I would give him a bit of bread—I gave it him, and he said, "Do you want to buy a brooch?"—I said, "What do you want for it?"—he said, "What will you give me?"—I said, "Sixpence"—he said, "Not sixpence"—I said, "I will give you a shilling," and I bought it—I asked how he came by it—he said he found it at the fair—he asked me to buy the ring, but I said I had no more money—I did not ask him how the came by that—on the 20th a neigh
bour came in, and in consequence of what she said I took the brooch to Mr. Buckland.

ELIZABETH JANE EVANS. I saw the prisoner about two o'clock on the morning of 19th Oct.—he had a ring on his right-hand finger, a brooch is his shirt, a chain round his neck, and a watch in his bosom—he came to the door, and said, "Here is a stunning ring"—he took it off, and gave it me to look at—I said it was a diamond—I said, "You never came by this honestly"—he said, "That is nothing to you"—he said he bought the watch for 2l.—I said, "If you had 2l., I should have thought you would have bought a suit of clothes with it"—he said, "I did not but it; I conjured it into my pocket."

JAMES POTTER (policeman.) I took the prisoner into custody, and told him I wanted him to go with me about Mr. Buckland's watch—he said he found the watch in his pocket—he said he sold the brooch to a woman at the bottom of the hill for 1s., and that he had found it in his pocket.
Prisoner. You asked me how I came by the things, and I said a young man gave them to me. Witness. You did afterwards.

GUILTY. Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

208.
HENRY FORT
, embezzling 5l., the moneys of
William Harris, his master; having been before convicted of felony.

p.rs:
Prisoner. I am guilty of this offence, but not of having been before con
victed.

div1.p:
JOSEPH THOMPSON (policeman, T 62.) I produce a certificate of the pri
soner's former conviction at this Court—(read—Convicted, June, 1842, trans
ported for ten years)—the prisoner is the man—I have not the least doubt of him—I picked him out in the yard—I told him he had a wen on his throat, and pulled down his handkerchief and found it.
Prisoner. I am not the man; when the Deputy-Governor called me out, you said I was the man. Witness. He did not call you out.

GUILTY. Aged 25—
Transported for Seven Years.

209.
WILLIAM BROWN
, stealing 1 picture, 1 coat, and 1 snuff-box, value 2l. 10s., the goods of
Benjamin Hooper; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 18.—
Confined Four Months.

210.
DAVID WESTHORPE
, stealing 1 lantern, value 7s. 6d., the goods of
William George Bracegirdle and another.

WILLIAM GEORGE BRACEGIRDLE. I live at Thames-cottage, East Green
wich. I have one partner—I missed a lantern from our premises—it was safe on Friday evening, 26th Nov., and the prisoner was found coming out of the room with it at three o'clock the next morning—he had broken in—we missed a great many things.
SAMUEL PARKINSON. I produce this lantern—last Saturday week, at three o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoner coming out of the window with it.
Prisoner's Defence. I go to work every morning at four o'clock; I only came out with it just to look at it; I did not see what it was in doors, the place is so dark.
----WESTHORP. I am the prisoner's mother. He is quite deficient of intellect—his father is ill in bed.

211.
JAMES SAUNDERS
, stealing 1 coat, value 1l. 7s., the goods of
James Whittome.

JAMES WHITTOME. I am a clothier, and live in Church-street, Greenwich. On 13th Nov., at half-past four in the afternoon, I was in my shop—the pri
soner came and bargained for a pair of trowsers—I missed, half an hour after
wards, a coat, which had been safe at half-past four o'clock—I went to Mr. Smith, the pawnbroker, and found it—this is it (produced)—it is mine.
Prisoner. I was not in the town. Witness. I am sure he is the man.
HENRY PATTISON. I am a pawnbroker. This coat was pawned by the prisoner—I am sure he is the man.
Prisoner. I was not there; I went down by the half-past six o'clock steam-boat; I had not been in the town five minutes when I was taken.

GUILTY. Aged 25.—
Confined Three Months.

212.
EMILY NEWMAN
, stealing 1 gown, value 8s. 1 shawl, 6s. and 2 handkerchiefs, 2s. the goods of
Ann Plummer; and 1 handkerchief and 1 coat, 11s., the goods of
Thomas Montague.

ANN PLUMMER. I am single, and live at Woolwich. The prisoner lived in the same house—on 20th Oct. she and I slept in one room—I missed a gown, a shawl of mine, and a coat and a handkerchief of Thomas Montague's—they
were all in one room—they were gone, and the prisoner was gone ✗—this is my gown (produced).
WILLIAM EVERDEN. I am a pawnbroker. I produce this gown—it was pawned by the prisoner.
Prisoner. I certainly took the coat, but I was persuaded by my husband to do it.

ANN PLUMMER
re-examined. The husband was not there.

GUILTY. Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

213.
ALFRED DOWSTEAD
, stealing 4 scarfs, value 15s. 8 handker
chiefs, 18s. and 3 rings, 3l. the goods of
John Farnaby Cartor his master; to which he pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 29.—
Confined Nine Months.

214.
SARAH BAILEY and
ANN WATERMAN
, stealing 28 yards of Orleans cloth, value 1l., the goods of
John Orrick Kennard.

WILLIAM KENNARD. I am in the service of John Orrick Kennard, a linen-draper, of the Broadway, Deptford. On 15th Nov., about a quarter before five, Waterman came for a pennyworth of thread, and Bailey took a piece of Orleans cloth off the board—this is the cloth—here are twenty-eight yards of it—it is my master's.

JOHN WHITE (policeman, R 180.) On 15th Nov. I was the Broad
way—I saw the prisoner in company for a quarter of an hour—I knew them, and watched them—I saw them look into Mr. Kennard's window—they both left the window and went to the shop door—Waterman went in, and Bailey put her cloak over this cloth, which was on a stool, and walked off with it—I crossed the road and took her, and took the cloth from under her arm—she said, "Don't make a noise about it"—I sent her to the station, and took Waterman as she came out of the shop door—I told her she was charged with stealing this cloth with Bailey—she said she knew nothing about it, but she certainly knew Bailey.

BAILEY—
GUILTY. Aged 27.—
Confined Six Months.

WATERMAN—
NOT GUILTY.

215.
ANN WATERMAN
, again indicted for stealing 36 yards of plaid, value 2l. 14s., the goods of
Isaac Watts and another.
JABEZ WHITEHEAD. I am in the service of Isaac and William Watts, of Deptford. On 20th Oct. I saw thirty-six yards of plaid safe—I missed it in the evening—I believe this is it—it is my master's.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You are not sure about it? A. It corresponds in every respect with what we had—there is no mark on it—I know it by the pattern—I knew by the book, the quantity there was of it before it was lost—I had not measured it myself—there are six persons in our shop—it was in my department—I had handled it and placed it at the door in the morning—I bought it, and know the length of it from the manufac
turer's mark, but the mark is not on this piece—it is much wider than plaids generally are.
RICHARD BARRON. I am in the service of Mr. Nash, a pawnbroker—this plaid was pawned by the prisoner for 5s. on 23rd Oct.
Cross-examined. Q. You have know her some time? A. Yes; she was

a regular weekly customer, bringing things and taking them out again—this is new—I believe her to be a dress-maker—she often pawned new things and took them out—the duplicate of this was produced to me by the officer.

JAMES KNIGHT (policeman, R 308.) I found the duplicate in the pri
soner's house, in the front room down stairs.

Cross-examined. Q. Who were in the house? A. Three or four chil
red, and four women went with us from the adjoining house—it was in a small box on the table—the prisoner told me it was her house.

GUILTY. Aged 42.—
Confined One Year.
(The were two other indictments against the prisoner.)

216.
JOHN DODMAN
, embezzling 3l., the moneys of
John Cross Charles Walton, his master; to which he pleaded

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 30.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.

div1.p: (There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

div0.p: SURREY CASES.

div1.p:
217.
THOMAS BROWN
, stealing, at
St. Mary's, Newington, 20 yards of satinet, value 10l. the goods of
Richard Mitchell, in his dwelling-house.

WILLIAM LANGLEY. I am assistant to Mr. Richard Mitchell, a draper, of 19, Newington-causeway. On the morning of 18th Nov., the prisoner and another person came to my shop, the other asked for some bundle handker
chiefs—whilst I was serving him, the prisoner walked down to the lower end of the shop, went inside the counter, took up some pieces of satinet, and put them under his great cost—he then walked up to his companion, who I was serving—I said to him, "You have some silks under your coat"—he made no reply, but his companion, who had selected a sixpenny handkerchief, threw down a shilling, and both ran out of the shop, leaving the shilling and handkerchief on the counter—I got over the counter and ran after them—I laid hold of the prisoner about two doors away, and said, "You must come back with me, you have some silks under your coat"—I brought him back to the shop, and left him in charge of a neighbour, while I went up stairs to inform my master—when I came down satinet was on the counter—I had not seen it before I went up—the neighbour is not here who I left in charge of the prisoner, but Mr. Stillwell was also present—the other man escaped—the satinet is worth 10l. or 12l.—I have patterns of it here, but the stuff itself.

HENRY STILLWELL. I am a leather-shaver. I saw Langley lay hold of the prisoner, and followed them to shop—while Langley was gone up stairs I saw the prisoner, in a stooping position, pull from under his coat two pieces of satinet, and place them on the counter—they were the same that were afterwards produced before the Magistrate.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How do you know that?
A. By seeing them with the striped edge, and the same size that I had seen on the counter—I know nothing of the quality.

WILLIAM LANGLEY
re-examined. The pieces I have brought here were taken off those pieces that were found on the counter when I came down stairs—they were cut off at the police-court in my presence.

WILLIAM BOYCE. I am foreman to Mr. Richard Mitchell, in the silk department. I put the pieces of silk on a shelf behind the counter, at the end of the shop the night before—when I came down in the morning I saw them lying on the counter—they were the same I had put away—the house is in the parish of St. Mary, Newington, and is Mr. Mitchell's dwelling-house.

GUILTY. Aged 46.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

218.
WILLIAM PLUMMMER
, breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
William Hilton, at Lambeth, and stealing therein 1 sovereign; 10 half-crowns, 4 shillings, and 6 sixpences; his moneys.

FRANCES HILTON. I am the wife of William Hilton, of 25, Windmill-street, Acre-lane, in the parish of Lambeth; it is his dwelling-house. The prisoner worked for me twelve months ago, sometimes for half a day—on Wednesday morning, 17th Nov., I left home about nine o'clock, leaving my husband at home—when I got outside I saw the prisoner near my pales—I went to Lambeth workhouse, and returned about half-past twelve—my husband was at home, and let me in—he said we had been robbed—I found the room all in confusion, a desk was broken open, and a sovereign wrapped in paper, some half-crowns, shillings, and sixpences, 52s. altogether, gone—they had been safe when I went out—a chisel which belongs to my husband, and was kept in the back wash-house, was in the desk—the prisoner knew where it was kept—he knew where every nail in the house was—he had not been in the house for twelve months.

WILLIAM HILTON. I recollect my wife going out last Wednesday—after she was gone I went out—I bolted and locked the front door, and went out at the back door—I did not see anybody come until my wife came—when I went to open the door for her I found it broken open—I had seen the prisoner that morning about eight o'clock, just opposite my garden.

WILLIAM JESSE (policeman, P 138.) About two o'clock on Wednesday afternoon, in consequence of hearing what had happened, I went to the prose
cutor's house—I found the back-door had been forced open, and the staple drawn—the desk was also forced open with an iron chisel, which was in it—it exactly corresponded with the marks where it had been forced—I went through the washhouse-door into the garden, and there found footmarks on the path leading from the side-gate to the back-door—I went in search of the prisoner, and found him between one and two o'clock next morning, in bed, at his father's house—I told him I wanted him for robbing poor old Mrs. Hilton again—he said, Oh, that was all right, for he had not been from his poor old father three minutes all day, and his mother said the same—I searched the house, but found nothing—I observed his boots, and thought they corresponded with the footmarks I had seen in the prosecutor's garden—I took them next day, and compared them—I had covered over the marks with garden saucers—I put the boot down into the mark—I looked at them before doing so, and saw they exactly agreed—they are peculiar boots—the

toe-plates are off, and on one of the boots there are four nails across—I produce them—they have not been soled by a regular shoemaker, but cobbled up—I am sure they corresponded with the marks before I applied them.

THOMAS LOCK. I live at 22, Windmill-street—I saw the prisoner on 17th Nov., between nine and ten o'clock in the morning, standing against some posts near Hilton's house—he walked off towards some buildings near there—I saw him again in the afternoon at those buildings.

GUILTY.** Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.

219.
JOHN CHITTENDEN
, forging and uttering an order for the delivery of 7 pockets of hops, with intent to defraud
Francis Nash and others.—Two other COUNTS, calling it a request; and four others, stating his in
tent to be defraud
Robert Collins.

ROBERT COLLINS. I am a hop-factor, 17, Maze-pond, Southwark—I know the prisoner—he came to me in the beginning of Oct.—I showed him a sample of hops that went by the name of "Andrew's hops" from the grower, the bulk of which that was a sample was lying at Messrs. Nash, Hicks, and Co., Pickle-herring wharf—I saw him again on 8th Oct.—he said he could sell those hops if I would take 70s. per cwt. for them—I had mentioned 75s. as the price—I told him I would take 70s., provided they were sold to a respectable person, and delivered and sold in my name, and for me to receive the money—he said he had sold them for 72s.—2s. was his profit—he said he had sold them—he had not bought them—he said he could sell them at 72s.—I said, "Whatever you sell them at beyond 70s., shall of course be your profit"—he then said he had sold them for 72s., to Messrs. Haynes and Son, maltsters, of Paddington—he did not say anything about the invoice till the Tuesday or Wednesday—I referred to the "Directory," to see who Messrs. Haynes and Son were—I found their name there, and said to the prisoner they had been living there seven or eight years—he said he had known them twenty years, and that they were respectable—I said, "Will you give an undertaking to pay for them, if Messrs. Haynes do not?"—he said he would, and he did give it—the policeman has it=the hops were said he would, and he did give it—the policeman has it—the hops were worth about 22l.—he asked for an order for their delivery, and I told him I would send the order to Mr. Haynes, and inclose him the invoice—on that he said that Mr. Haynes had not any hops by him, and that he wanted them immediately, that he was going to Paddington, and would take the order with him—I gave him this order (produced)—this writing, which is on the back of it, was not there then—I believe it to be the prisoner's writing.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. The prisoner is what is called a hop-factor, is he? A. Yes—I had never spoken to him before this—he has had samples once or twice from our establishment, which he has re
turned, not having effected sales on them—I entrusted him with the samples of these hops—he did not come back and say he had succeeded in selling one pocket—he said he could sell the whole of them, if I would take 70s., and mentioned Haynes and Son as the purchasers—the hops were then lying at Nash's wharf—I did not understand from the prisoner that there had been some previous misunderstanding between him and Nash—he never told me anything about it—I have heard that Mr. Nash has lost a great deal of

money by the prisoner's family—the prisoner did not tell me at first that I had better make out the order in Haynes' name, as there was a misunder
standing between him and Nash—he told me nothing of the kind—I made out the order in the name of Haynes and Co., not on the understanding that the prisoner could obtain them as purchasers—I had no personal communica
tion with Haynes—the prisoner was the broker, or go-between, between me and Haynes—he was to act on my account, receiving commission on his own—he said he thought Haynes would purchase the hops, and I gave an order, made out in Haynes' name, for their delivery from the wharf—I received the undertaking from him at the same time—according to the custom of the trade, the payment would have been made on the second Saturday after the sale—that would have been on 18th Oct.—the prisoner was taken into cus
tody on the 31st—I think I learned on Monday, 11th, that the hops had been delivered from Nash's wharf on Mr. Haynes' order—I did not see the order—I did not then make any inquiries, as the money was not due—I did after the 18th, and then found out that Mr. Haynes had given no such order—the pri
soner did not call on me on 20th or 21st Oct., and say he had sold one pocket to Haynes and Son, and received the money, and when he sold the remainder he would pay me the whole—he called on me before the day of payment, and said he had sold one of the pockets; and he called on me after the day of payment, and told me he had sold the others, but had not received the money—he did not mention the purchasers.

MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Had you at that time discovered that Haynes and Son had not given the delivery order? A. Not at that time—I went to Mr. Haynes on the Tuesday after the day of payment, and ascertained that he had never given the delivery-order for the seven pockets—the prisoner came the day after, and said he had sold one pocket to Haynes—I had seen him be
tween the time that he got the order from me, and the time I went to Haynes and Son—he did not then say anything about the sale of the one pocket—when he first came he said that Haynes and Son would purchase the seven pockets of hops—I made out the invoice, and gave it him, to give it to Haynes and Son, for me to call with him on the Saturday to receive the money—I think that was on the 11th, the Monday after—they were delivered on the Saturday—it was before the money became due—he said he wanted the invoice, to leave at Messrs. Haynes'—I learned from Mr. Nash that the hops had not been delivered.

COURT. Q. Did no conversation pass between you and him on Monday, the 11th? A. Yes—he asked me for the invoice, to take to Mr. Haynes, and said that he had sold them for 78s., not for 72s., he wished me to make out the invoice to Mr. Haynes for the 78s., and to go with him on the Satur
day to receive the money—I did not see any more of him till the following week, the Wednesday after the day of payment—no other names besides Messrs. Haynes and Son were mentioned when I gave him the invoice.
MARY DAVIS. I am the wife of Nathaniel Davis. The prisoner came to our house on 8th Oct., and left a paper for my husband—he was out, and I gave him the paper at night.

NATHANIEL DAVIS. I am a town-carman. On the evening of 8th Oct. I received from my wife this order for the delivery of seven pockets of hops from Pickle-herring wharf—I gave it to my man, James Lynch, on the morning of the 9th—the prisoner came to me that morning, and asked if I had got the hops out—he afterwards told me they were to be delivered at the Brighton-station, in Dean-street, to wait for orders—I carted away the seven pockets
of hops, and delivered them at the station—I went to the station three or four days afterwards, got five pockets of hops, and delivered them by the prisoner's direction, to Mr. Gobel, in Cole-street.

Cross-examined. Q. They were left there not to go by railway, but in a private warehouse? A. Yes, for orders—I do not know whether they were to be re-delivered out to purchasers—they were not delivered there to be sent down the line.

JAMES LYNCH. In Oct. last I was in Davis's employment—on the 9th Oct. I took an order from him to Mr. Hicks, at Pickle-herring wharf—I gave it to Mr. Hicks, in his counting-house—I received seven pockets of hops, and took them to the railway-station.

EDWARD SAMUEL HICKS. I am in partnership with Francis Nash and another. In Oct. last there were seven pockets of Andrews's hops in my warehouse, belonging to Mr. Collins—they were delivered up to the bearer of this order—when delivered to any other person, the order is required to be endorsed by the party to whom the order is made deliverable—this order is made deliverable to Haynes and Son, and endorsed as from them, to be de
livered to the bearer.

Cross-examined. Q. Do I understand that in the course of business you never deliver without such an endorsement? A. The order is always en
dorsed—I cannot say there never was a delivery of goods without such an endorsement: but there never should be—the order is always endorsed when a party does not apply personally for them—deliveries do take place without endorsements, when the holder of the order applies himself—the prisoner did not himself apply to me.

MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Would you have delivered up these things with
out the order signed, "Haynes and Co.?" A. Certainly not.

THOMAS HAYNES. I am a dealer in malt and hops, at Paddington, and carry on business with my two sons. This order, signed "Haynes and Son," is not my writing—I know nothing about it—I never authorized any person to sign it—I know the prisoner—I saw him on 7th Oct.—he sold me a single pocket of hops by sample, marked "Andrews"—he brought the hops to me on the 9th, and I paid him for them at the rate of 78s. per cwt.—they came to 5l. 3s. I think—he had two other samples with him, but I did not pur
chase either of those—he sold me only the one pocket—he produced a bill of them made out in his own name, which I have here—(produced)—it relates only to the one pocket—I had no other dealings with him—he did not show me a delivery-order, or an invoice to Mr. Collins—I paid him the money—he did not mention Mr. Collins's name.

Cross-examined. Q. The bill is from Collins to you, is it not? A. No, from the prisoner—I never knew the name of Collins till afterwards—I have known the prisoner twenty years—he has been a hop-factor during the whole of that time—I never knew him an any other capacity—on this occasion I asked him if they were his own hops, because we occasionally buy of growers through factors—I did not suppose he was a grower—he said they were his own—he had other samples with him—he said nothing about having more of Andrews's hops—I should not have been disposed to have bought more at any price—I did not want any more—he has been a respectable man ever since I have known him—his dealings have been so, as far as I have been concerned with him—I have frequently given orders where I have bought through fac
tors, to deliver hops to my name, with an endorsement or a regular written order.

MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. If a delivery-order was made out to you for the delivery of certain hops, and you afterwards transferred it to another parts, would you write your name afterwards? A. I should write it as this is written, on the reverse side—this is not in the writing of any one in my firm.

THOMAS HINES GOBEL. I am a hop-factor, in High-street, Borough—I saw the prisoner on or about 8th Oct.—he asked, if he sent in seven pockets of hops, whether I would advance him 5l. or 6l.—I told him I would—he then said, "But I can sell them myself"—I said, "I will not take them in, and send them out without a commission"—he agreed to allow me a commission of 4s. a pocket—on 12th Oct., about one or two o'clock, he called at my office and said, "The hops are in your warehouse, but there are but five pockets; I should like to have the money," and at the same time he said he had sold six pockets of new hops, marked "Pearson," if I could take 67s. for them—I had lent him a sample of them at 70s.—I told him I would ascertain it from the men when they came from dinner—I did so—I saw him again on 22nd, and he wanted two of the five pockets marked "Andrews"—he had two pockets away on 22nd, the other three remained.

GEORGE WILD (policeman M 94.) I took the prisoner into custody on 31st Oct.—I told him he was charged with stealing the hops from Mr. Collins—he said Mr. Collins gave him the order in his own handwriting, to obtain them from Messrs. Nash and Hicks, of Pickle-herring wharf—he said, "I sold them to Messrs. Haynes and Son, of Paddington"—on Monday, 1st Nov. I got three pockets of hops from Mr. Gobel—I have not got the undertaking here—I cannot exactly say whether I have list it or whether it has been mis
laid—I received it from Mr. Collins—I have searched for it and cannot find it.

Cross-examined. Q. Where have you searched for it? A. In my pocket-book—I cannot say exactly when I saw it last, but I had it here when we came to give instructions for the indictment—I recollect having it last Thursday—I and the solicitor had it—I cannot recollect whether I put it into my pocket-book again—I have been a policeman nine years—we sometimes ask a prisoner what he has to say to a charge—they sometimes admit it themselves without being asked—I do not try to screw it out of them—the prisoner said Mr. Collins knew all about it.

CHARLES WELBORN. I am the solicitor for the prosecution—I saw the undertaking, and made a copy of it, which I compared with the original, very particularly—the last time I saw the original was in the office here, on 17th—the policeman then had it in his hand—I had it in my hand and gave it back to him, because I was not concerned for Mr. Collins, only for Messrs. Nash—I kept the delivery-order, and produce it.

Cross-examined. Q. Then Messrs. Nash and Hicks are the prosecutors of this indictment? A. They were ordered by the Magistrate to prosecute—(the order was here read, the endorsement was as follows, "Deliver to bearer seven pockets of hops, as per order other side, Haynes and Son, Oct. 9, 1847." The copy of the undertaking being read, was as follows:—"I undertake to pay Mr. R. Collins of seven pockets of hops, marked, 'Andrews, of Brook-street, Kent, 1846,' provided Messrs. Haynes and Son do not pay the same on or before Saturday next. J. Chittenden, Oct. 8, 1847."
(The prisoner received a good character.)

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 42.—Recommended to mercy.

div1.p:
(
There was another indictment against the prisoner, charging a larceny of the goods in question,
on which Mr. HUDDLESTON offered no evidence.)

220.
GEORGE MORDEY
, feloniously killing and slaying
Robert Mordey: he was also charged on the Coroner's inquisition with the like offence.

AMELIA HAMMOND. I am the wife of Thomas Hammond—on Friday, 1st Oct., I lodged at 64, Little Surrey-street, Blackfriars-road—the prisoner occupied the back parlour ground-floor of that house for about two months—I occupied the front parlour—I knew the prisoner's brother, Robert, who is now dead—he was in the habit of coming to the prisoner in the daytime—he was there on Friday the 1st; I saw him—a lad named Vincent also used to help him—I had seen him on other days, but not on that day—the prisoner took the room of me, and said he worked at a cabinet-maker's shop, in the Westminster-road—I never saw him doing anything but rolling papers for three weeks or a month before this occurrence—I saw him filling pa
persin the yard, behind his parlour, on Friday morning as I was hang
ing out my clothes, but I did not notice what with—I never heard any noise—on Friday afternoon I was sitting at work in my room about half-past five, and heard a dreadful report all in a moment, like fireworks—I saw a lot of smoke in the passage, and I opened the window, jumped out, and ran away—I then came back again, thinking of my father, who was in the house, and the first person I saw was the little boy, Robert Mordey, all on fire, coming out of the street-door—he was fourteen years old—I never saw him afterwards—about moment after, the prisoner came out of the door with his hands and hair terribly burnt—I asked him what he had been doing, and he said something had flown out of the fire—another report of the same sort then went off—he said he would go in and put the fire out, and he went in—I did not see him again—I went in again in about five minutes—the house was in a smother, and perceived a smell of sulphur—I went into the room the prisoner occupied when my husband came home, about eight o'clock in the evening—it was terribly burnt, the windows all broken, and the door blown off.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. You did not know what the occupa
tion of the prisoner was? A. Not till about three weeks or a months before it happened—I was aware then that he was doing something with papers—when he came out of the room he returned immediately, for the purpose of putting out the fire—he succeeded in putting out the fire, with the assistance of Naylor—he has been in the hospital—he was very much hurt—I have only known him since he came to lodge there.

THOMAS HAMMOND. I live with my wife in the front parlour of this house—on this day I got home a little after seven in the evening—I had known the window, rolling paper—I do not know what was in it—I never through the window, rolling paper—I do not know what was in it—I never saw what he was doing—I never had any conversation with him about what business he was—I searched the room after I came home, and found some fireworks in the table drawer—they were flattened—what I had seen him rolling were round—on the following Sunday morning I found nearly three-quarters quarters of a pound of gunpowder under part of a loaf, in a brown paper bag, on a little sideboard—I did not know the boy Robert at all—I never saw him till he was dead.
Cross-examined. Q. Were there not two boys? A. Yes—I did not see
them on the Tuesday before, letting off fireworks in their yard—I never saw anything of the kind.

JAMES WHEELER. I am a shoemaker—I lodged in the back room, over the kitchen, in the house where this happened—I was at work by myself, heard the noise of an explosion, and directly my place was filled with sulpher—I got up and opened the door to escape, but not, the smell was to strong—I dot down stairs after a while, and got into the street—I was nothing of the prisoner—I have seen him and his wife at work rolling papers—I have not seen him fill them—I believe they contained something combustible—I asked him a few days before that, as I passed the window, if that was the way made fireworks—I do not think I said "fireworks"—I said, "I never saw anything of the kind before, is that the way you do it?" and he said they did not fill them—I understood they were fireworks, or something of the sort—I do not recollect the exact words that passed—I did not take particular notice of them—his wife said they did not fill them there, they did not it for fireworks—that was in his presence—she said they were filled at their sister's, that they only made the cases—the prisoner made on answer.
Cross-examined. Q. Were there not two boys there? A. Yes—I never saw them letting off fireworks of any kind in the yard.
MR. RYLAND. Q. Have you seen the prisoner letting off fireworks in the yard? A. Yes, a day or so before this happened.

THOMAS GRAY. I am a cap-maker, and lived with my family in this house, in the back room first-floor—I, my wife, and children, were at home when the explosion took place—it sounded like the pop of a gun—my win
dow was open, and smoke came in—I took the child up in my arms and opened the door, and the moment I opened it the flames and smoke rushed up to my face—I put the child in some one's arms, jumped out into the yard, and they threw the child after me, my wife jumped out, and when I came back I found her lying on her back in the yard—after that I con
veyed her through the passage—after I jumped through the window I heard three different reports, the same as the first—the prisoner came into the yard and said, "Oh my God, look at my hands!"—I did not notice whether his hands were burnt—I knew the two boys—I have seen the prisoner's brother Robert at work there, filling the squibs with gunpowder, I believe—the prisoner has been sitting at the window when I have seen Robert mak
ing squibs—I did not see Robert after I got out of the house—I saw the other boy, James Vincent, come out at the back door—he seemed to be burnt—the shirt on his right shoulder was burnt—he got over into the next yard—I have seen the prisoner rolling papers for crackers—I spoke to him once on the subject, two or three weeks before the explosion—I said, "Sup
pose they were to explode"—he said, there was no danger of that, he always worked them damp—he gave me a cracker to feel, and it was quite damp—on the Tuesday before, I saw the prisoner let off two squibs in the yard, and then Vincent came and let off another—on the Thursday, the day before the explosion, he let off a lot of what I think he called Roman candles—one was much larger than the others, and he exploded a lot of gunpowder on the window-sill, which filled my room with smoke—about a fortnight before that I saw him put a quantity of squibs on the side of the hen-house, in the yard—I did not see what he did with them—on the Tuesday before the accident I told him he ought to be ashamed of himself, he was worse than a child—my wife is not here—she was burnt a good deal, and has been confined to her bed a fortnight.

Cross-examined. Q. It was in the yard that you saw him left off the Roman candles? A. Yes—it is a small yard—I certainly did not ask him to let them off—I saw them—he said he always worked them damp—he had them rolled up in a wet cloth—I did not see them on the hob, or anything of the kind—I have seen him take them out of the cloth, and fold them, and I have seen him tying them up—I never saw him put them on the hob—I cannot say how long the prisoner's brother had been working there—I saw the prisoner put a quantity of gunpowder on the hen-house on one occasion to dry—I never saw anything put there to dry but the powder—that was on the Thursday, the day before the explosion—I saw him filling the squibs by the hen-house—what I saw in his room was about a week before the accident—I saw Vincent let off a squib in the yard, on the Tuesday before—the boys worked in the same room with the prisoner—I saw them at work at fireworks—I have only known him by his coming to the house—he had lodged there I should say about two months—I believe he was very much hurt, and in
jured himself—he has been in the hospital till this time.

GEORGE BOWN. I lodged in the house, and was present when the ex
plosion took place—I have known the prisoner five or six weeks, during which time, he, his wife, and the two boys, have been employed in making fireworks—I do not know what they did with the cases when they had made them—they were little round cases—I saw them rolling them one morning, and at another time I saw them filling them, with what I supposed to be gunpowder.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know the age of the prisoner's brother? A. About 16.

CAROLINE BOWN. I am the wife of the last witness—I was at home when this explosion took place—I was just going to have my tea when the door was burst open—on the day before, the prisoner called me to the window of his room, which was open, to look at some candles that he was making—I am not certain whether they were Roman candles—I understand that is the name they go by—I went—he told me to look at them, and he threw a little bit of something black, about the size of the end of my finger, into the fire, to show me how it went off—it made a buzzing noise, and went up the chimney—I said to him, that it was a very dangerous business, and I did not much like it, and many accidents happened from it—he said he never had met with any himself—I said, "It is that that gives you courage, "and he said, "Yes"—that was all that passed—I know fireworks when I see them—I have seen squibs, crackers, and Catherine wheels about at times, since the prisoner came to live there—I saw one of the Roman candles in the yard, by the dust-hole—I did not see who did it—the prisoner was there at the time, and I have seen him in his room making squibs and crackers.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you seen the boys letting off squibs in the yard? A. I once saw Vincent, the least of the two, with a Catherine wheel on a stick at the street door.

WILLIAM MORDEY. I am the father of the prisoner, and also of the de
ceased—his name was Robert—he was thirteen years old—I saw him last alive on the evening of 1st October—I saw him dead on the following day—the prisoner was much hurt, and taken to the hospital—I called on him while he was there—he inquired after Robert—I asked him how the accident occurred—he told me there was something on the hob of the stove which caught fire, and flying back among the other materials, caused the explosion—he said. "Never mind me, go and see how my brother is"—that was all he said
Cross-examined. Q. He was very seriously injured himself? A. Very much so—I stated at the inquest that my son was 14 years old—that was my mistake.

GEORGE ROPER. I am one of the dressers at Guy's Hospital—the lad Robert Monday was brought there on Friday evening, 1st Oct.—he was very extensively burnt over the whole surface of the trunk, head, and arms, and everywhere except the legs—everything was done for him that could be done—he lived about eight hours—there was a sulphurous smell about his cloths, and a smell of gunpowder and black marks about the skin.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe that the prisoner only came out of the hospital yesterday, for the purpose of taking his trial? A. Yes—he is now out danger—he was very dangerously ill for three weeks—his life was despaired of for a considerable time.
COURT. Q. When did the boy die? A. About eight or ten hours after the injury.
(The Court was of opinion that this evidence was not sufficient; it not being clearly proved that the accident resulted from any act of the prisoner's.)

221.
THOMAS MORDEY
, again indicted for feloniously killing and slaying Edward Vincent.
MR. RYLAND offering no evidence, the prisoner was

222.
JOHN WILLIAMS
, stealing a coat, value 30s., the goods of
Wil
liam John Padden; to which he pleaded

223.
WILLIAM SPOONER
, stealing 5 yards of cloth, value 4s. 97 yards binding, 5s. and 1 3/4 yards serge, 2s.
also, 90 buttons, value 4s. 6d., the property of
John Cartwright, his master; to both of which he pleaded

GUILTY.—
Confined Nine Months.

224.
WILLIAM JINKINS
, stealing 1 breast-pin, value 10l. the goods of
William Hughes, in his dwelling-house.

WILLIAM HUGHES. I am a jeweller, at 117, High-street, Southwark—it is my dwelling-house, and is in the parish of St. George-the-Martyr, South
wark—on Monday, 1st Nov., between two and three o'clock in the afternoon, the prisoner came in—I was him standing looking at a tray, containing diamond pins—I watched and distinctly saw him take a pin off the cushion, and place it in his pocket—I went into the shop, and stood there till he had selected a pin which he said he would take on the following Saturday—he left half-a-crown deposit on it—he was then going out—I said, "You will excuse me, but before you leave the shop I wish to put my hand in your left hand pocket"—he thrust his hand into his pocket and took out this diamond pin which I produce, and dropped it in the tray amongst the others—it is mine—it is worth 10l.—he attempted to get out of the shop—I caught hold of him, my young man came to my assistance, and he bit his arm very severely.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALF. Q. Where were you? A. In a little lobby, divided from the shop by a glass partition—there is a parlour beyond that lobby, where I was when the prisoner entered—when he took the pin I was in the lobby, watching him through the glass—I waited in the lobby perhaps three minutes before he took it—when I was in the inner room I saw him looking, as I fancied, at a diamond which I had placed in the window, price thirty-five guineas—the first thing I saw was that he was looking at the pins in the tray—my young man turned his back to go to the window to get some more pins, and then the prisoner placed his left hand over the tray, took this pin and placed it in his pocket—I could see sufficiently well to see that he took it from the tray—I swear I saw the stem of it in his left hand—he looked at nothing but pins—he put his hand in his left pocket, pulled his hand out, and opened it afterwards—I stood nearly opposite him—I then came and taxed him with it—he put his hand in his pocket, and took this pin and dropped it from his hand—I saw it drop—I am certain he did not put his hand in the tray and point to a pin and say, "Is that the pin?"—it dropped from his hand—they were stuck on a cork when he took it out, but he dropped it down afterwards—the mark of it is very much rumpled.
COURT. Q. Are you sure you saw him put his hand in his pocket? A. Yes; positive of it—it is a breast pin.

FREDERICK GEORGE HEARLE. I am in the employ of Mr. Hughes. On 1st Nov. the prisoner came to look at some diamond pins—I showed him a tray which I placed on the counter—he wished to see some others—I turned to get another tray and put that on the counter—he then selected a pin from the first tray, and left me half-a-crown and his name—Mr. Hughes spoke to him, and he dropped this pin on the tray from his hand.
WILLIAM THRUSSELL (policeman 148 M.) The prisoner was given into my custody—he made an attempt to get away as I was conveying him to the station.

GUILTY. Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.

225.
RICHARD PITTS and
JOHN DAVIDSON
, stealing 1644 boxes of Lucifer matches, value 1l. 2s. the goods of
William Falconer.

WILLIAM FALCONER. I am a lucifer-match maker, at Durham-place, Lambeth-road. Pitts was in my service—I dismissed him on Saturday, 23rd Oct., but told him to be back on Monday or Tuesday—Davidson had been in my service, but had left me about two months—these boxes of lucifer-matches are mine—they were in a loft up stairs at my factory, 7, Duke-street, Red Cross-street—they were all packed up in paper parcels, a dozen boxes in each—I saw them safe on Saturday 23rd, when I paid my hands, probably about four o'clock, when I left the premises—I did not miss these till my boxmaker sent me work—I had been to the premises, and seen the place appear all right—it was locked up and the lock had been taken off—I found on the Wednesday that it had been broken—but these had been taken out on Monday night—the lock had been broken, but not the door.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALF. Q. Who told you that the place was broken open? A. Mr. Lewis, who supplies me with boxes—he lives in Grey-street, Blackfriars; he not here—I was at the place after Saturday, but had not noticed that it was broken—landlady found the lucifer matches under the prisoner's bed—the gave information, and the policeman took them—I sell a great many matches—these are of different sorts—there is only one person in London that had got the manufacture of these—the place was safe in Saturday night, and every parcel that ought to have been there was there—I
counted every parcel—Pitts counted them with me—there were 173 gro✗—I missed thirty-one gross and some more dozens—eleven gross and someothers were found under the prisoner's bed.

COURT. Q. They were safe on Saturday, locked up, and on Wednesday you found the lock broken and they were gone? A. Yes—when I found the place was broken I got another lock, and locked it up again, and went to the station-house.

Davidson. Q. You never missed anything while I was at work for you? A. Yes, I missed a silk handkerchief the day you left—I cannot prove that you were the thief, but I suspected you—I never saw it again.

JOSEPH MIDDLETON. I live in Duke-street, Southwark—the prisoners lodged at my house—on Wednesday morning, 27th Oct., they came home at twenty minutes past one o'clock—they had not been at home all night—I let them in—they did not go into the room up stairs—they stopped and went out again in five or ten minutes, leaving the door open from that time till day-light—I was called up into their room about a quarter before nine, and found between eleven and twelve gross of boxes of matches, some in a white cloth, and some thrown about—I gave information to the police, and they took the matches and the prisoners.

Cross-examined. Q. How many beds were in that room? A. Five—seven persons slept in the room that night, all working-men—the others were all in bed—I know the prisoners went back after they had been in—I went into the room to call one of the men to get up at past four o'clock, and then the prisoners were out—my street door was open when I called the man up—I never knew the prisoners to be out at night before—the others are in bed from ten to eleven—no one is out afterwards, unless they tell me they are not coming in that night—these matches were done up in paper—there was a white cloth round some, and an apron round others—one was undone, the paper was broken, and they were loose about the room.
Davidson. Q. Is not the house kept open all night? A. No, I never allow my door open for anybody.

WILLIAM PINDER (policeman, M 278.) I took the prisoners—Mr. Middle
ton gave me the boxes—when I went up in the room with the prisoners they said they knew nothing about them—I took the prisoners to the station—Pitts said they were made at his mother's—Davidson said, "No, they found them in a parcel as they went up stairs to bed."

WILLIAM FALCONER
re-examined. Q. Is this the way your matches were done up? A. Yes, they were done up by Pitts and three other boys.
JURY to JOSEPH MIDDLETON. Q. Did you see any parcel brought in by the prisoners when you let them in? A. No—I had a light.

PITTS—
GUILTY. Aged 19.

DAVIDSON—
GUILTY. Aged 19.

226.
DANIEL THOMAS
, for embezzling 8s. 8d., the monies of
Charles Hellier, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 35.—
Confined Six Weeks.

227.
SUSAN MITCHELL
, unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.
HENRY READ. I am a grocer, in the Dover-road. On 8th Nov. the

prisoner came in for half an ounce of tea—she paid me a sixpence—I put it in the till—there were ten or twelve shillings there, and two or three new sixpences, with "sixpence" on them—the one the prisoner gave me was an old one of George the Third's reign—it remained in the till a minute or two—I then took it out and gave it to the officer, West.
Prisoner. I never was in that man's shop. Witness. I swear it—I am satisfied she was.

MARY ADAMS. I am bar-maid in the Red Lion, in Blackman-street. On Monday, 8th Nov., between twelve and one o'clock, the prisoner came for half a pint of beer—it came to a penny—she gave me a sixpence—I told her it was a bad one—she said she was not aware it was bad—I insisted on her giving me good money, and she gave me a penny—I kept the sixpence in my hand—West, the officer, was in the house, I gave it to him.
Prisoner. She never told me it was bad till after it was given up.

WILLIAM CHAPMAN. I am a baker, in Bermondsey New-road—the pri
soner came to my house on 8th Nov. for 1lb. of bread—she put down a sixpence and a farthing, so as to have 4 1/2d. change—the sixpence was bad—I look it and bent it—an officer came in—I gave it to him and he took the prisoner.

THOMAS WEST (policeman, M 249.) I was in company with Whitlamb on 8th Nov.—I saw the prisoner come out of Mr. Read's shop—I went in and got this sixpence (produced)—I followed her to the Red Lion—I heard Adams say, "This is a bad sixpence"—I beckoned to her, and she gave it to me—(produced)—I saw the prisoner again about nine o'clock in the even
ing in Bermondsey-road, and followed her to Mrs. Chapman's—Whitlamb went in there.
JOHN WHITLAMB (policeman, M 89.) I went into Mr. Chapman's shop that evening and got this sixpence—(produced)—I took the prisoner, and found 1s. 8d. on her silver, and some odd pence.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL. I am inspector of coin to the Mint—these three sixpences are all bad—two of them are of the reign of George the Third, and they are from the same mould.

GUILTY. Aged 23.—
Confined Six Months.

228.
ANN HOWARD and
JANE PAGE
, for a like offence.

CAROLINE ASHTON. I am the wife of Thomas Ashton, a licensed victualler, of Bride-lane. On 2nd Nov. a tall young man came to the bar and called for a pint of beer—he gave me half a sovereign—I tested it on my finger; it was good—the prisoners came in at the other door—Howard asked for a glass of port wine and a glass of porter—she threw me down a sove
reign—I gave her the half-sovereign I took from the man, and said, "I will give you 9s. 6d. from the till"—she said, "Oh dear me, how light this is!"—I said, "It is a good one"—she said, "I would rather have silver a great deal"—I said, "Nonsense, it is good"—Mr. Mitchell said, "Here is silver," and gave her four half-crowns—I rung the half-sovereign on the counter, and am prepared to say it was a good one—Mr. Mitchell had not examined the half-sovereign before he gave her the silver—the moment Howard had re
