ceived the four half-crowns the prisoners left—as soon as Mr. Mitchell took the half-sovereign he pronounced it to be bad—he showed it to me—I wrapped it in paper, put it on a shelf, and afterwards gave it to the officer.
Cross-examined by MR. METCALF. Q. You tested the half-sovereign! A. Yes, on my finger, a rung it on the counter—I have been ten years in business, and never took a bad one before.
FREDERICK MITCHELL. On 2nd Nov. I saw the prisoners at my sister's shop—I gave them four half-crowns for a bad half-sovereign.

SOLOMON ISAAC LEE. I was at Mrs. Ashton's on 2nd Nov. A man came and gave Mrs. Ashton a half-sovereign—the moment he had paid that the prisoners threw down a sovereign for what they had taken—Mrs. Ashton gave them the half-sovereign she had taken of the man, and went to get the silver—I heard Mrs. Ashton ring the half-sovereign—it sounded like a good one.
THOMAS GARFORTH (policeman, L 151.) I went to Mrs. Ashton's on 3rd Nov.—she gave me this half-sovereign—I have kept it ever since—she made this cross on it.

JAMES RUSHALL. I keep the Rose and Crown in Torrington-street, Surrey. On 2nd Nov., about five o'clock, a tall man came in and asked for a glass of gin—before I could serve him the prisoners came in—the man put down a half-sovereign in their presence—Howard asked for a glass of shrub and a glass of porter—before I served her I took the half-sovereign of the man, and knowing they had been there before, I looked at it very particularly, and am able to swear it was a goof one—I put it down in the receas, expecting Howard was going to ask for change for a sovereign—the prisoners then asked for change for a sovereign—I took the half-sovereign, looked at it parti
cularly again, and gave it them with the rest of the change—as soon as I had turned my back Howard said, "This half-sovereign feels very light; I will thank you to change it"—Page said, "Oh my dear! I think it is good; do not give the gentleman the trouble to change it"—Howard said, "I think it is light; I would rather have silver"—I took the half-sovereign, went to the station, got a policeman, and gave the prisoners in charge—Howard wanted to take the half-sovereign out of my hand—she said, "Let me look at it"—I said, "No, you have seen it before"—I had know the man who came in before, and I should know him again.
Cross-examined. Q. How did you test the half-sovereign? A. I looked at it very particularly—I have taken many hundred pounds in half-sovereigns.

JOHN DAVIES (policeman, L 46.) I was called to Mr. Rushall, on 2nd Nov., about five o'clock—I received from him this half-sovereign, and Howard attempted to take it out of his hand—she said, "Give me the half-sovereign; I will be at the loss of it rather than have any further brother about it."

Cross-examined. Q. Did you search the prisoners? A. No—they were taken directly to the station, and female searched then—only 9s. 6d., and 1 1/2d. were found on Howard—they had to go a quarter of a mile from Mr. Rushall's to the station.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL. These half-sovereigns are both counterfeit, and cast in the same mould.

HOWARD—
GUILTY. Aged 22.

PAGE—
GUILTY. Aged 19.

229.
CHARLOTTE JONES and
JOHN EDWARDS
, for a like offence.
ROBERT KIRK. I live with Mr. Aldis, who keeps a cook's-shop, in the

London-road. On 4th Nov. the prisoner Jones came in for one pennyworth of pudding—she gave me a George the Third or George the Fourth sixpence—I turned it over two or three times, and doubted it, by its being worn so smooth—I put it into the till, and when I had taken up the halfpence, took it up again, and thought it was good—I gave her the change—she left the shop—there were two Victoria sixpences, not worn at all, in the till, and some other silver; a policeman came in, I took the sixpence that Jones gave me, from the till, tried it with my teeth, and found it was bad—I threw it into the till again—the policeman told me to take it out; I did, and put it on the shelf—I afterwards gave it to Rowe—I am sure I gave him the same I received from Jones.

WILLIAM WRIGHT FLOOD. I am assistant to Mr. Yates, a chemist, in the Borough. On 4th Nov. Jones came to the shop for some pills—she offered me a sixpence—I had it in my hand when May came into the shop—he wished to look at it—I gave it him—he took Jones into custody.
Jones. Q. Did you not say it was good? A. I said I thought it was silver.

DANIEL MAY (City policeman, 357.) I was on duty on 4th Nov.—I saw the prisoners—I knew them, followed them, and saw Jones leave Edwards and go into Mr. Aldis' shop—Edwards stood outside, a little distance off—Jones came out and joined him—I followed them to Mr. Yates' shop—Jones went is and left Edwards outside—I went in and received this sixpence—Edwards passed by once or twice while I was in the shop—I took Jones into custody—Mr. Yates' shop is three-quarters of a mile from Mr. Aldis'.

Edwards. Q. What statement did you make at the station? A. I am not aware that I made any—I did not state that the women went into a cook's-shop, and the man into a baker's shop—I did not state that the woman went into a shop in Blackfriars-road.

COURT. Q. You swear that Jones went into two shops, and left Edwards, and then joined him again? A. Yes; they went into nearly a dozen shops, and he was outside of all of them, except public-houses, there they went in together.
HENRY ROWR (policeman.) I received the sixpence from Kirk in Mr. Aldis' shop—I took Edwards outside Mr. Yates'—I found in his pocket two small parcels of tea, and a small parcel of butter and sugar.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL. These sixpences are both counterfeit, and cast in the same mould.
Jones' Defence. Edwards was not near me when I went into the shop, he was at the corner of the Mint, talking to my brother; I went into the doctor's shop for the pills.

JONES—
GUILTY.* Aged 25.

EDWARDS—
GUILTY.* Aged 31.

230.
MARY BETHELL
, stealing 2 blankets, value 10s. 1 gown, 5s. 1 pair of shoes, 1 shawl, and 1 towel, 8 s. the goods of
Moses Pritchard, her master.

AUGUSTA MARY ANN PRITCHARD. I am the wife of Moses Pritchard, of Queen-square, Walworth. On 15th May the prisoner came as a servant—I afterwards missed the blankets and other articles stated, and a great many other things—she left on 2nd of June, at the side gate, and drew the staple to let herself out—the article produced are mine.
GEDRGE QUINNEAR (policeman, P 201.) I received information, and went to the prisoner's house in Camden-town—she named several articles which

she said were recoverable—I went to the pawnbroker's and found them—these are them—the prisoner was stopping at her father's, a greengrocer, in Hampstead-road—she acknowledged taking the things, and said she went down to her brother's in one of the shires.

GUILTY. Aged 23.—
Confined Four Months.

231.
GEORGE CLARKE
, stealing 1 sack, value 2 s. and 1 1/2 bushel of oats, beans, and chaff, 2s. the goods of
William Shott, his master; and
MARY ANN PHILLIPS
, feloniously receiving the same; to which

CLARKE pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 45.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.
—
Confined Three Months.

WILLIAM SHOTT. I am a corn-merchant, at Thomas-street, Horsleydown, Clarke was my horse-keeper—he had a mixture of oats, chaff, and beans to give to may horse—I could not miss any of it—this sack produced is mine, and the mixture also I believe—it corresponds with mine in all respect in all respects.

THOMAS WEST (policeman, M249.) On Friday, 12th Nov., about seven o'clock in the evening, I saw a cart standing in Cross-street, Horsleydown—Clark was standing at the back of it—I saw a sack, containing something is it—I went into Fair-street, and watched Clark—he went to Mr. Phillips' shop, remained there two or three minutes, came out, went to the cart, and took the sack into Phipps's shop—it had about a bushel and half of some
thing in it—I saw him go through the shop into the back parlour—Phipps was sitting at the table in the parlour—Clarke remained two or three minutes—he put the sack down, and came out—I remained outside a few minutes, them went in, and asked Mrs. Phillips if she had any corn brought within the last hour into her shop—she said she had not—I asked her if a man with a white smock-frock who walked lame, had brought anything there—she said he had not, but she knew that man—I went into the back parlour, and saw this sack there—I asked her who brought it—she said she did not know, it was brought when she was putting the children to bed—I asked her what time she put the children to bed—she said an hour and half age; that when she came down she saw it there, and did not know who put it there—Clarke had taken it in about three minutes before—I have shown this sack to Mr. Shott—it bears his name—it contains about a bushel and a half of beans, oats, and chaff.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You opened the sack yourself? A. Yes—I waited in the back parlour till Phillips husband came in, about half an hour afterwards—Whitlamb, another officer, was with me, but he said no-thing—I did not go up stairs to see whether the children were gone to bed.

PHILLIPS—
NOT GUILTY.

232.
MARY ARNETT
, stealing 5 purses, value 9s. 6d. pencil-cases, 7 thimbles, 1 locket, and 1 brooch, value 1l. 8s. 6d. the goods of
Thomas Longhurst, her master.

THOMAS LONGHURST. I am a tea-dealer, at Camberwell-green. The pri
soner had been in my service, and was about to leave me on the morning of 10th Nov.—I thought it necessary to search her boxes, and found the articles named in the indictment, and other things—she begged of me to forgive her, and said she would never do so any more.
Prisoner. I hope you will be merciful.

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 23.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.

div1.p:
233.
MARGARET DORE
, stealing 1 handkerchief, value 4d., the goods of
Mary Ann Pitt; and 1 pair of gloves, 4d. the goods of
Benjamin Pitt, her master.

MARY ANN PITT. I am the daughter of Benjamin Pitt. The Prisoner was our servant—I lost a handkerchief about a mouth or six weeks before she was taken—my handkerchief was found on her at the station—this is it—( produced)—it is mine—these glove are my mother's—they were found on the prisoner.

GEORGE BEAK (policeman, V 164.) I took the prisoner to the Section—I found this handkerchief and gloves on her—she said she did not know any
thing about them.
Prisoner. My mistress made me a present of the gloves, and I said I did not want them; I lived six months with her, and she did not pay me my wages.

MARTHA PITT. I did not give her these gloves, but another pair very much like them—she has got them in her bundle now—I owe her some wages, but not six months'—I owe her 1l. 0s. 6d.—the ladies I work for will not tell me the value of all the articles.

234.
MARGARET DORE was again indicted
for stealing 1 petticoat, value 1s., the goods of
Charlotte Randall.
CHARLOTTE RANDALL. I am servant to Mrs. Rann, of Upper Bedford-place. Mrs. Pitt washed for us—sent her this petticoat to wash—it was not returned—it is my property.
GEORGE BECK (policeman, V 164.) I found this petticoat in the prisoner's bundle at the station-house.
Prisoner's Defence. I made the petticoat, and brought it from Ireland.

GUILTY. Aged 17.—
Confined Four Months.

235.
GEORGE BROWN, alias Dixon
stealing 15 sovereigns, 1 half-crown and 10 shillings, the money of
Michael Horden Peek.

MICHAEL HORDEN PECK. I am a dry-salter, at Southwark-bridge. The prisoner was in my service about four months—on the 16th Oct. I gave him fifteen sovereigns, a half-sovereign, and 10s. in silver, to take to Spa-road, Bermondsey, to Mrs. Julia Adams, a manufacturing chemist—Mr. Barber manages her business for her—I have done business for them for years—the prisoner did not come back—I did not see him again till the Tuesday fort-night—I charged him with this—he made no reply—it was his duty to come back, and he did not.

Cross-examined by MR. BALDWIN. Q. Are you a manufacturing chemist? A. No, a dry-salter—I supply muriate of lime and oil of vitriol—I had connexion in business about two months ago with a man named Bateman—I know Marshall-street—I have no place of business there, Bateman had—when I did business with him there was an illicit still there—I had nothing to do with it, I had no benefit from it—I used sometimes to get sweet spirits and allum.

HENRY BARRY (policeman, M 171.) I took the prisoner at the corner of King David-lane, Ratcliff. On the 2nd Nov. there had been hand-bills published, and a reward of two guineas offered—I said I took him for robbing Mr. Peek, in Southwark-bridge-road—he said he did not know Mr. Peck, and his name was not Dixon, it was Brown—I said, "I know you are the

man, I must take you over the water"—I took him to Mr. Peck's—he iden
tified him as George Dixon, and the man who has stolen the money.

HENRY BARBER. I manage the business fro Mrs. Julia Adams, of Spa-road. On 16th Oct. I did not receive fifteen sovereigns and other money, brought by the prisoner—Mrs. Adams lives there, but does not interfere in the business at all.

GUILTY. Aged 21.—
Confined Nine Months.

236.
ELIZA HAYWOOD
, stealing 19 groats, the moneys of
George John Spreadbury, her master.

GEORGE JOHN SPREADBURY. I am a licensed victualler, and live In Ber
mondsey
square—the prisoner was in my service. On the 7th Nov. I had 502 groats there in a bag in my bed-room drawers—I thought it necessary to mark them, and missed nineteen—the officer brought them to me—they were what I had marked.

GEORGE LANKESTER (policeman, M 236.) I followed the prisoner, and brought her back—she had seventeen fourpenny-pieces—she had purchased this victorine with two fourpenny pieces at a shop in the street—she said the money was her own, and she worked hard for it—she pleaded guilty before the Magistrate.

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 25.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.

div1.p:
237.
WILLIAM GREEN
, stealing 6 shillings and 1 sixpence, the money of
William Thomas, from his person:
also 1 petticoat, 3 gowns, 1 waistcoat, and 1 tea-put, value 1l. the goods of
William Stanton: to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 22.—
Confined Six Months.

238.
CATHARINE PLANT
stealing 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 2 half-crowns, 1 sixpence and 6 halfpence, the property of
James Lynch, from his person; having been before convicted.

JAMES LYNCH. I am a lighterman, and live at Horsleydown. Between one and two o'clock, on the morning of 8th Nov., I was walking down Tooley-street—the prisoner came up to me—I Shoved her away two or three times—she shoved me down Weaver's-lane—we stood there about five minutes—she then left me—I had a handkerchief, two half-crowns, and other money, just before—the moment she left me, I put my hand into my pocket, and they were gone—no one could have taken them but her.

THOMAS TATE (policeman, M 267.) I took the prisoner—I found two half-crowns in her right-hand, and a sixpence and two-pence down her bosom—she told me to keep the money that was in her hand and say nothing about it.

Prisoner's Defence. It was my own money, which a gentleman gave me in the street just before; this man said all the money he had was 3d., and if I did not go down Weaver's-lane with him for that, he would give me in charge.
JOHN WOODHOUSE (police-sergeant, M 13.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction—(read—Convicted Oct., 1841, and confined three months)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY. Aged 27.—
Transported for Seven Years.

239.
ELIZABETH BAILEY
, stealing 1 shawl, and 2 petticoats, value 2l. 10s. the good of
William Thomas Pennington, her master.
(The prosecutor did not appear.)

240.
JAMES FULCHER
, embezzling 1l. 6s. 10d., the moneys of
Frede
rick Hall, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 26.—
Confined Nine Months.
(There were two other indictments against the prisoner.

241.
HENRY BATES
, feloniously forging and uttering a receipt for 1l. 4s., with intent to defraud
Joseph Hankins; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 32.—
Confined One Year.

242.
WILLIAM CLAYTON
, stealing 1 pair of boots, value 2s. 1 cap, 6d. 1 pair of trowsers, 2s. 6d. 1 frock, 1 handkerchief, 2 stockings, value 2s. and 3 sovereigns, the property of
Edward How, in a vessel on the Thames.

EDWARD HOW. I am master of the Arab—it is lying at Mill-hole, on the Thames—I left the articles stated and my money safe in my bed-case in my state-room, on 12th Nov.—I missed them on Sunday morning the 14th, bet
ween five and six o'clock—the prisoner was my apprentice—he deserted the ship, and could not be found—I went after him, and found him at Islington—he was brought out of the theatre to me by his uncle—I asked him how he could do what he had done—he said he knew nothing about the money—I gave him in charge to the officer—he was dressed differently to what he was before—he had my boots on his feet—my cap was found in a bag which was in his aunt's possession—he was a good boy.

WILLIAM SIMMONDS, (Thames police-constable, 62.) I went to the pri
soner's lodging with the caption—I found the prisoner at the City of London theatre.

EDWARD HOW
re-examined. Q. How did you know it was the prisoner's lodging? A. From the Marine Society's office—I afterwards spoke to the prisoner about the things found in the bundle—he said nothing about them, but on the Sunday morning he told me he took three sovereigns out of my box.

CAROLINE ELTHAM. I am the prisoner's aunt. He brought the bundle to my house at eight o'clock on the Sunday morning—I got an order, and took him to the theater—he told me the captain gave him the boots—there was a crack at the side—I got them mended.

p.rs: GUILTY of stealing the boots. Aged 17.—

div1.p:
243.
THOMAS WALKER,
THOMAS MOORE , and
JOHN MORLEY
, stealing 1 copper, value 1l. the goods of
Samuel Joseph Hadlow, fixed to a building: and
DAVID HYMAN
feloniously receiving the same.

WALKER pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 13.

MOORE. pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 11.

MORLEY pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 13.

—
Confined Three Months.

SAMUEL JOSHEPH HADLOW. I live at 15, Peckham-grove, Camberwell. I know Hyman—he is a dealer in marine stores, in Burdett-street, Camberwell—on the night of 5th Nov. I lost a copper, and on the 8th Nov. I went to Hyman's shop—I saw him, and gave him notice that my house had been broken on the night of 5th Nov. and a copper and the gate-bell, the keys of the doors, and the brass furniture from the doors had been taken—I asked

him if anything had been brought to his shop—he said, "No"—I called to him again a few days after—he said to me, ""Have you heard anything of your copper?"—I said, "No," and said, "All these things, you know, make good for trade."

GEORGE QUINNEAR (policeman, P 201.) I went to Hyman's house in consequence of what Walker said—I saw Hyman—I asked Walker in his presence if that was the man he sold a copper to on Saturday night, 6th Nov.—he said it was—Hyman denied it; he said, "I can assure you it in wrong, I did not buy a cooper of him"—Walker said, "I did sell the copper to you; you asked what I wanted; I said, 'Six shillings'; you weighted it, and gave us 6s. 2d. you asked where we lived, and we told you in John-street, Albany-road; you lit your pipe and was going with us, and we ran away"—the cooper has not been found.

ELIZABETH RICE. I live in Southampton-street. I heard about a cooper, and on Saturday, 6th Nov., went to Hyman's house—his wife said he was not at home—I waited—he soon came home—I said to him, "I understand my boy brought a cooper here, and it is a very wrong thing to buy anything from children without their parents knowing it"—he came out from his shop—I said, "It is a very serious thing"—he said, "You keep your boy in your house, it will soon blow over if you do not let him go along with the rest."

SAMUEL RICE. I live with my father, Thomas Rice, a blacksmith, in Southampton-street. I know Walker, Moore, and Morley—on Saturday evening I went with Moore and Walker to 3, Peckham-grove—they told me to get up to the window—I broke a square of glass and got in—there was a copper there—we took it away to a house up steps, and they would not buy it—we took it to Hyman, and he gave us 6s. 2d. for it, and chucked it on the rag heap—he did not weigh it—my brother found it out, and told my mother, and I told my mother where I took it to.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. Have you told us all that occurred? A. I took my mother where I took the copper—I and Walker went into Hyman's shop—we told him the copper was our father's, and we lived at 4, Bath-street.

HYMAN—
NOT GUILTY.

244.
THOMAS WALKER and
THOMAS MOORE
, stealing 1 copper, value 10s. the property of
John Hough, fixed to a building; and
DAVID HYMAN
, feloniously receiving the same.

WALKER pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 13.

MOORE pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 11.
HENRY RICE. On Saturday, 6th Nov., I went with Walker and Moore to 3, Peckham-grove—we took a copper out, took it to one place, and they would not buy it—we took it to Hyman—he bought it for 6s. 2d.
Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. What time was it? A. Between six and seven in the evening.

GEORGE QUINNEAR (policeman, 201 P.) I took Walker—he pointed out Hyman's shop to me—Hyman was there, and Walker said, "That is the person I sold the cooper to on Saturday night, and the cooper I had on Friday I sold to the woman"—Hyman and his wife were both present—Hyman
said, "I can assure you, policeman, it is false; I bought nothing of the kind"—Walker said, "We asked six shillings for it; you weighed it, and gave us 6s. 2d."
Cross-examined. Q. ✗ copper he referred to belonged to Mr. Hadlow? A. He referred to two the copper he sold on Saturday evening to Hyman belonged to ✗ugh—it was the copper taken on Saturday, 6th Nov.

ELIZABETH RICE. I went to Hyman's shop on Saturday night, 6th Nov.—I said, "I understand my little boy has brought a copper here; you should not buy anything from these children unless their parents know it; you should inquire of the parents"—he came out from his shop—I said, "This is a very serious thing"—he said, "You keep your boy in away from the other boys, it will soon blow over."

JAMES NASH. I am coachman to Mr. John Hough—he has an empty house at 3, Peckham-grove—I saw a copper safe there at five o'clock in the evening of 6th Nov.—I missed it about eight o'clock the same evening.

SAMUEL JOSEPH HADLOW. On 8th Nov. I went to Hyman's shop—I said, "Have you had a copper brought here, and other things, "which I described, "for sale"—he said, "No"—I said, "I have had a house broken into, and these things stolen"—he said he knew nothing of them—I described the copper to him—I was standing looking at his stall a few days afterwards, and he said to me, "Have you heard of your copper, Sir?"—I said, "No, I have not indeed"—after a moment's pause, he said, "All these things you know make good for trade."

Cross-examined. Q. Had he known you before? A. I had bought a stove of him two or three weeks before—I am not in business now—I was a stockbroker for many years—I dealt in stock about a month ago—I know what they mean by a lame duck—I believe it was never said of me that I was the most notorious liar in the Stock Exchange—I never heard it.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did you ever sell your copper to Mr. Hyman? A. No—my character is quite different to a most notorious liar—I can bring 100 witnesses to my character.
MARY FRY. The boys, Walker and Rice, came to me with a cooper on 6th Nov.—I refused to buy it—my place is about five minutes' walk from Hyam's.
Cross-examined. Q. They told you it belonged to their father? A. Yes.
MR. O'BRIEN to HENRY RICE. Q. What time did you sell the copper to Hyman? A. We took it between five and six o'clock, took it to Fry's about seven, and sold it to Hyman about eight.
(Hyman received a good character,)

HYMAN—
GUILTY. Aged 27.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.
—
Confined One Year.

245.
ANN DAVIS
, stealing 1 watch, value 5l. and 1 chain, 5l., the goods of
William Herring, in his dwelling-house.

JANE HERRING. I am the wife of William Herring, of George-street, Camberwell. On 8th Nov. the prisoner came to me for a lodging—I let her some—she said she was taken ill, and asked for some brandy—she went out, and left the door open—I had a watch in the house, and when she was gone I
missed it—she did not come back—no one could have taken it but her—she did not hire the lodging, and did not return.
Prisoner. I never was at Camberwell in my life. Witness. She is the same woman, I should know her from a thousand.

GUILTY.—
Confined Nine Months.
(There were two other indictments against the prisoner.)

246.
MARY STEPNEY,
CAROLINE MOGGERIDGE , and
THOMAS BATTOCK
, stealing 1 pocket-book, value 9d. 1 comb and 1 pair of scissors, 2d. 13 sovereigns, and 1 half-sovereign; the property of
Patrick Shorlin, from his person.

PATRICK SHORLIN. I am a licensed hawker—I have been lodging for some at time Mr. Morgan's at the Rose and Crown Inn, Wandsworth. On Tuesday evening, 2nd Nov., I was in the tap-room at the Rose and Crown—I was a little the worse for drink—I saw Stepney there, I did not notice Moggeridge—there was more than one woman there—I treated them and other persons with beer—I took out a sixpence first, and then half-a-crown to pay for half a gallon of ale—I had my purse in my pocket—there were thirteen sovereigns and one half-sovereign in it, and I cannot tell how much silver—I recollect that Stepney had her arm round my neck—I laid my head on the table, on my hand—I do not know how long I laid so—I afterwards felt in my pocket—my purse was gone, and my pockets, turned inside out, I had not a halfpenny left—I ran to the bar, and shouted out that I was robbed—I lost my money, that brought me to my senses—the landlord came from the back parlour when I shouted—he said, "It would have been a good job if you had lost your head"—I ran to close the door to get a policeman—the landlord would not let me shut it—he said he was master of his own house—I went out and got a policeman—I was back in a few minutes—the people who had been in the tap-room were then all gone—when I was going to bed I missed my comb, my scissors, and pocket-book, which had all been in my pocket—I have seen the scissors again—I had had them nearly twelve months—I had them from Henry M' Leary—I left Mr. Morgan's house after that—he proposed to get me 3l.
JURY. Q. Which side did you lose your purse from? A. My left hand breeches pocket—Stepney sat on my right side.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALF. Q. After Stepney had put her arm round you, what did you do? A. I could not tell—I was quite drunk till my money was taken away—I had gone to sleep, I do not know for how long—there were a good many people there—I had seen Stepney before—she was in the room before I went there—I saw a bar-man there, beside the landlord—Mr. Morgan offered me 3l. that I should not make my appearance before the Magistrate, and he promised me 1l. after Christmas.

GEORGE ROSEWELL. I am a coal-porter at Brewhouse-lane, Putney. On 2nd Nov. I was in the tap-room of the Rose and Crown, about half-past eight o'clock in the evening—the tap-room was full of people—Shorlin was treating them all round—Stepney went and sat on his left hand side—she sat first on one side of him and then on the other—her arms were round his waist, and his hand round her neck—he was tipsy—about half-past ten o'clock I heard him say he was robbed—Stepney was there then, and the other two pri
soners—Stepney and Moggeridge, were sitting in the same box with Shorlin, and Battock in a box on the opposite side of the room—when Shorlin said he

was robbed Stepney went out, and I suppose it exceeded five minutes before she was in again—I did not see what became of Moggeridge—the room was full—Moggeridge sat on the opposite side of the box to Shorlin—there was a table between them—there were four of five men in the same box.

WILLIAM RICHARD FRANKLIN. I am pot-boy to Mr. Morgan, at the Rose and Crown. Shorlin lodged there for some time—on the evening of 2nd Nov. he was treating the people with liquor—I saw Stepney sit on his right hand side—Moggeridge was on the other side of the same box—Shorlin had a hawker's license—I saw Stepney look at it in his presence—I afterwards heard him call out that he was robbed—Stepney, Moggeridge, and others, were then in the box with him—they got up and went out of the room—Stepney and Moggeridge were not away more than five minutes; they then came back—I have seen Shorlin with gold about him at different times; two, or three, or four pounds.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALF. Q. That was some time before? A. Yes—he sometimes drinks a good deal—he was very drunk that night—Rosewell was drunk when he went away—I do not know whether he was at the time of the robbery.

ELIZA KING. I am the wife of William King, of Garrett-lane, Wands-worth. Stepney and Moggeridge lodged with me—on Thursday morning, 4th Nov., the prisoner, Battock, came to their lodgings—Stepney was taken on the Thursday night, and of Friday Moggeridge came and asked me if I would swear to the scissors, as that was the only thing that would betray them—I have examined these scissors.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. They wanted you to do a little bit of perjury? A. Yes—I had lent them a pair of scissors—they wanted me to swear I had lent them a pair, and that was true—I cannot tell whether these scissors are mine—they look very much like mine—I believe them to be mine—they were tight when I lent them, they are loose now—they are not uncommon scissors—I have not had mine back.

MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you not say first, at the police-office, that you thought they were yours, and then say you thought not, because yours were not broken in the rivet? A. I said I did not think they were—I did not re
member that they were broken in the rivet.

AMELIA WILLIAMS. I live in Garrett-lane, Wandsworth. I know Stepney and Moggeridge by sight—on the morning of 6th Nov., Moggeridge came to my house and had some breakfast with me—she brought a basket, and left it at my house—the officer took it—it was in the same state as when she brought it.

JAMES WEBB (policeman, V 134.) On 4th Nov. I went with Povey to the house in Garrett-lane, where Stepney and Moggeridge lodge—they were together in bed—I took Stepney into custody—I saw a basket at the side of the bed—I asked Stepney whether the whole of the contents of that basket was her property—she said, "Yes"—I found in it some ribbon, several trifling things, and this pair of scissors produced—I asked if they were hers—she said they were, and said whose did I think they were—I saw Shorlin in Stepney's presence as soon as I got out of the lodging-house—I asked him to describe his scissors—he described them, in Stepney's presence, as being very old and loose in the rivet—he had not seen them then—they corresponded with that description—I took Stepney to the station, and afterwards searched the room.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did you tell Shorlin that a pair
of scissors were found? A. I said to him, when I came out of the lodging-house, "You have lost a pair of scissors, have you not?"—he said, "Yes, I have"—he knew I was going to take the prisoners.

CHARLES POVEY (policeman, V82.) I went with Webb—we found the scissors and basket—I found between the sheets and the bed an old purse, with some money in it—Stepney said it was hers, and she knew what it con
tanined.

WILLIAM TRACEY. I am a linendraper, at Wandsworth. On 3rd Nov., between four and five o'clock, Stepney came to my place, and another girl, who I have no doubt was Moggeridge—they purchased these articles, and paid about 4s. for them.
JAMES STAPLENTON COLLINGBOURNE. I live in Wandsworth. I know Step-ney and Moggeridge by sight—about three weeks ago they came and bought two pairs of boots of me, at 5s. 6d. a pair.

JAMES DAVID CHANDLEY. I am shopman to Mr. Hyde, a linendraper at Wandsworth—I believe it was on 4th Nov., Stepney and Moggeridge came together and bought two shawls, at 10s. 6d. each, and some lining for dresses—they laid out altogether 24s. or 25s.

PATRICK SHORLIN
re-examined. These scissors are mine—I had them about me on the day I was robbed—I had them twelve months—I described them to the policeman before he showed them to me.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What do you know them by? A. The rivet is loose, and here is a mark on one of the blades—this purse is not mine.

247.
HENRY BROWN
, stealing 9 wedges, value 11d., the goods of
Henry Lee and another, his masters:
also 1 saw, value 1s., the goods of
Wil
liam Smith: and 1 wedge, 6d. and 11 pieces of yarn, 6d. the goods of
Henry Lee and another, his masters: to both of which he pleaded

GUILTY.—
Confined Three Months.

248.
HENRY YOUNG
, stealing 1 wheelbarrow, value 12s. the goods of
William Langham; having been before convicted; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 17.—
Confined One Year.

249.
JOHN WHEELER
, stealing 40 bushels of oats, value 5l. the goods of
John Dudin, in a barge on the Thames.

JOHN ADCOCK. I am a deputy corn-meter, at John-street, Horsleydown. On Monday, 4th Oct., I went on board the Tennant—I was employed to deliver 330 quarters of oats, 260 into a barge called the Eclipse, and 70 to another barge—Hopkins acted as lighterman in taking the oats and stacking them in the Eclipse—he was convicted on this indictment last Sessions—he was in the service of Mr. Dudin—when I came up on deck, I saw a skiff under the bow of the vessel, and noticed seven or eight sacks in the skiff—I addressed myself to Hopkins—the prisoner might be then about three or four yards off—he was within hearing of what I said—I asked Hopkins whether Wheeler worked for Mr. Dudin—he said, Yes, he did, it was all right—Hopkins and Wheeler had some conversation—I saw Wheeler take the skiff away, and row it towards Prince's-stairs—I did not count the quan
tity in the skiff—there were seven or eight sacks in it when I came on deck.
Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. Where was Hopkins when you

spoke to him? A. In the Eclipse—the oats were being lowered down to him—I said, "You did not tell me you were going to load the skiff"—he said, "Yes, with five quarters'—I was acting as meter, and Hopkins as lighter
man, to Mr. Dudin—he had the management of it—I asked him whether Wheeler worked for Mr. Dudin—he said, "Yes"—I did not see any one but Wheeler in the skiff—it was about twelve or half-past twelve o'clock—there were several men in the Tennant.

JAMES HASTIE. I am a fellowship-porter—I was employed in delivering the oats—I saw the skiff come with three bundles of empty sacks—Hopkins and the prisoner were in it—the prisoner assisted Hopkins in passing the sacks out of the skiff into the barge—I saw the prisoner take two sacks from the side of the Tennant, and lay them down in the skiff—I called to Adcock, and told him what I had noticed—the prisoner took the skiff away—there ap
peared to be about five quarters in it, but we did not take notice—Hopkins said that Wheeler worked for Mr. Dudin, and it was all right—I should think the prisoner heard that—he stood on the barge—a boy came in the skiff, but he had been sent on shore—the prisoner rowed the skiff away.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know who was the owner of the skiff? A. No—I saw the prisoner take two sacks—I do not know who took the other—the sacks were not weighed—the oats were measured by Adcock—I do not know whether the prisoner heard what Hopkins said—the skiff went in the direction of Prince's-stairs.

JOHN DUDIN. I am a master-lighterman—Hopkins was in my employ; the prisoner was not—I did not authorize Hopkins to employ him—I found the skiff that has been mentioned at ten o'clock that night, with no oats in it—it had been in my charge that day—I had directed Hopkins to deliver the oats at Whiting's-wharf—I have been charged with the difference of the quantity that should have been delivered—I searched for the prisoner—I did not see him again till last Friday—such search has been made for him that I think the Thames police-officers would have found him had he been in the way—I have looked for him.

Cross-examined. Q. The prisoner has worked for you? A. I have no knowledge of his working for me—Hopkins had no authority from me to em
ploy any one—he could have rowed the barge himself with 260 quarters in it—I have done it—all but the quantity stolen was put into the barge—the skiff did not belong to me, but it was in my charge that day—I gave Hopkins instructions to hire twenty sacks.
GEORGE MADDOX (Thames-police inspector.) I have been in search of the prisoner since the 4th Oct.—I could not find him—I have missed him from that time.

JAMES LAMBERT. I saw the prisoner with his skiff of 4th Oct.—he asked me if I wanted a cast on shore—I said, "Yes"—I stepped in, and saw some sacks full—I do not know what they contained—the prisoner rowed to George's-stairs—I left him in the skiff—I do not know what was done with the sacks.

MR. O'BRIEN to JOHN ADCOCK. Q. Can you say that the prisoner must have heard you when you spoke to Hopkins? A. I cannot—I called out loud, and was near enough for him to hear—he stood with his back to me—he did not turn round to me to look.

GUILTY. Aged 38.—
Confined One Year.

250.
EDWARD PEARCE
, assaulting
Elizabeth Ford, putting her in fear, and stealing from her person and against her will, 1 watch, value 1l. 2s. and 19s. 6d. the property of
John Ford; having been before convicted. 2nd COUNT, of
Elizabeth Williams.

ELIZABETH FORD. I am the wife of John Ford, a cabinet-maker, of Brook-street, Lambeth. On the evening of the 1st Nov., I was in Kenningtes-lane, about ten minutes before eight o'clock—the prisoner spoke to me—I had seen him in the street before, and knew him well by sight—he got into talk with me about the weather—I went and had a glase of ale with him is Mansion-house-street, at a little beer-shop—while there I took out my watch to look what time it was—it wanted ten minutes to eight o'clock—the prisoner was present and the gentleman behind the bar—I came out of the door—the prisoner followed me—I bid him good night, and said, "Thank you"—I went straight down Mansion-house-street—when I got half-way down, I looked behind, and saw him following me—I kept on till I got to the end of the street—I turned, and saw him again—I turned to the left, to go down Kennington-row—I still saw him following me—I saw a turning with a pawnbroker's at the corner—I knew it brought me out opposite the school, and turned down there—the commencement of it is rather dark—I did not see the prisoner there, but as soon as I got round the corner he flew on me, and caught hold of me—I have not any doubt it was the prisoner—he threw me down, and he got my cloak open, and pulled the watch out of my bosom by the guard, and my purse with 19s. 6d. in it, and kicked me in the side—he did not break the guard, but wrenched the watch from it—when I was on the ground I saw him with my watch in his hand—he was gone almost in
stantly—while he was getting it, I was scrambling to get from him, but I was so confused that I could neither halloo nor speak.

Cross-examined by MR. MELLER. Q. What is your name? A. I suppose it is Elizabeth Williams—my husband's name is Thomas Williams—he left me three years ago, last June, and since then I have been living with Mr. Ford, about fifteen months—I do nothing for my living, Mr. Ford keeps me—I never was on the town—I first saw the prisoner on that night in Kennington-lane—I have seen him about the street before—I have seen him about New
ington, leaning on a post—I know nothing further of him—I am not in the habit of going to drink with any person that ask me, but I was thirsty—we had a pint of ale, nothing else—I had had some gin where I had been to tea in the afternoon—we had 6d. worth between four of us—that was where I changed a sovereign—it was about five o'clock—I had not had anything between that and the time I met the prisoner—a young man came into the beer-shop when the prisoner, and I, and the person who keeps the beer-shop were there—it could not be half an hour after I left the beer-shop before I was robbed—there are houses on either side of the street—I did not see any policeman there—I had a very great objection to the prisoner following me—I did not know what he wanted—I thought he was taking undue liberty—I should not allow it—I was not in the Spread Eagle, in White-hart-street, that night—I have not been in that house since the present landlord kept it—I was not at the King's Arms, in Chester-street—I was not in any public-house—when I came from where I went to tea, I came on till I saw the prisoner—I do not know Owen, who keeps a brothel—I did not ask the prisoner to go to a bro
thel with me—I will swear there was never such a thing said or thought of—there

was not the least expression of it on his part or mine—I did not say anything about paying a shilling for the room—I did not say I knew a place that would do instead of a room—nothing of the kind was mentioned—on my oath, I had not been with the prisoner that night—I did not go into a court with him—if he said that he had connexion with me it was not true—I had no wrangle with him about money—I was robbed once before. when the house was robbed, a year and eight months ago—I was not intoxicated that evening—I had been to tea at Vauxhall, and was going home to 70, Brook-street—I was not going the nearest way—I wanted to take something home with me—I left the prisoner at the door of the house, and had no more con
versation with him—a young man came into the public-house—he asked him for two farthings for a halfpenny, and he gave them to him—there were no persons passing where the prisoner robbed me—it was by the side of the pawnbroker's just against the wall—I wanted to avoid him, and I took a turning that would have taken me to kennington-lane—I saw him by the shop as far from me as the width of this Court—I did not notice whether I passed many persons in going from the public-house—I was knocked down in the mud on my left side—a woman was going into the pawnbroker's or standing by the front door, and I was by the side door, a little further down than the door—I was so frightened, I could not halloo—I screamed out after I got up when my fright was over—I do not know whether the woman was by the door then—I did not see her afterwards; I did go that way when I got up, I went to Kennington-lane, and turned to my right—I should think it is about a quarter of a mile from the station—I went to the station instantly—I did not abuse the prisoner because he did not give me money—I never spoke to him after I bid him good night.

MR. METCALF. Q. When the attack was first made, and this kick given, you were too frightened to cry out? A. Yes, but I got up and went to the station—I go by the name of Ford—I never answer to the name of Williams—the watch was my own, and the money Mr. Ford had given me.

GRORGE HARRIS. I keep a beer-shop, in Mansion-house-street. On the 1st Nov., Mrs. Ford and prisoner came into my beer-shop a few minutes after eight o'clock in the evening—Mrs. Ford called for a pint of the best ale—the prisoner said, "No, I take 6d. ale"—he called for a ping—they stood and drank it—they did not stop in the bar above ten minutes—I saw Mrs. Ford take a watch from her bosom and look at the time.

Cross-examined. Q. Did they speak? A. They said very little—the prisoner was talking to another young man part of the time—the prisoner paid for what they drank, and he and Mrs. Ford left together from the bar—I cannot say which went out first—Mrs. Ford appeared to have been drinking a little but to know perfectly what she was about—I thought so by her manner, not by her conversation—she said but very little in my presence.

JOSEPH RACKSTRAW (policeman, L 120.) I took the prisoner—I told him he was wanted for a highway robbery, and he was the beat judge whether he knew anything about it—he said he did not know—in going to the station he asked me whether it was a woman who preferred the charge—I said I did not know.

Cross-examined. Q. He went readily with you to the station? A. Yes; it was on Wednesday—I took him two days after the robbery—there was nothing found on him—this is the guard belonging to the watch, and the handle of the watch—it was left on Mrs. Ford's neck.
CRARLES BURGESS GOFE (police-sergeant, L 8.) I produce a certificate of
the prisoner's former conviction at Newington—(read—Convicted, Oct., 1837, and confined six months)—the prisoner is the man—I knew him before then, and I have known him since.

GUILTY.† Aged 36.—
Transported for Seven Years.

251.
DUDLEY RUSH
, feloniously stabbing, cutting, and wounding
Joseph George Simmonds, on the upper lip, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

JOSEPH GEORGE SIMMONDS. I am a lighterman, and live at St. Saviour's, Southwark—the prisoner lodged in my house four or five years—we were not good friends, we did not speak to one another at all—he paid his rent, and came into our room and took his meals with me and my wife, but found his own food—he came into our room on the night of 22nd Nov., between ten and eleven o'clock, he said he would sit there as long as he liked—I told him I wanted to get to bed—I asked him if he was going to stop in our house all night—he gave me no answer—I told him to go out, he would not go—he rushed past me, went to the cupboard, unlocked the door, got a knife, made a stab at my nose, and gave me a blow afterwards—he then chucked down the knife on the table, and ran up stairs to his own room—he struck my wife for taking my part.
Prisoner. Q. When I came home, did I go to the public-house after you and your wife? A. I went home about ten o'clock, and you followed us home.
COURT. Q. You were in public-house? A. Yes; my wife came after me—the prisoner then came in and sat on the other side of the house.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not cry out "Police!" on Sunday night, and make such a noise that I said I should leave the house? A. You said you should leave when it suited you—I did not tell my wife that the men on the wharf were chaffing and jeering me through you.

MARY SIMMONDS. I am the prosecutor's wife. The prisoner has lodged with us nearly five years—he had his meals with me and my husband—on the night of 22nd Nov. he was in our room—I had been to the public-house to my husband for the key of the door—if the prisoner had come home he could not get in—when I went into the public-house the prisoner sat there—my husband and I went home, the prisoner followed us, he had an altercation with my husband—I endeavoured to push him out of the room, and I got hurt—he struck my husband with his fist in my presence—I remained in the room, but not all the time—I said he should not sleep in the house that night, and went up stairs to take the beds away—I did not see anything else.
Prisoner. Q. Did you hear your husband say that I had made words on the wharf, and I should go on the Tuesday? A. You said you should go when the week was up—I did not see you take the knife.
JAMES WRIGHT. I am a surgeon—I examined Simmonds' lip on the Tuesday morning—I washed the blood away—I found a very small incised wound, it was of no consequence—it might have been done with a razor.
Prisoner. Q. Were there not several scratches on the side of his face? A. Yes.

FREDERICK FREEMAN (policeman, M 124.) I took Simmonds on the night of 22nd Nov., his mouth was bleeding and full of blood—I took the prisoner the same night—he was locked up in a room up stairs—he said, "I did not sec a knife, I did not do it"—Simmonds showed me a knife on the table with several small spots of blood on it.
Prisoner's Defence. I went up stairs; his wife walked up and said, as I was

going to-morrow night I might as well go to-night; some altercation occurred, she wanted to get into the room to take the bed; I let go the door, and she slipped in, and he ran out and called "Police!" and "Knife!" that is all I know about it.

PATRICK COLLINS. I am tailor. I have known the prisoner six months—he is of a very good temper when he is sober—he sometimes gets drunk—on Sunday night the Simmond's called out "Police!" and "Knife!"—he is in the habit of doing so—I do not think he is right in his head—on the Monday the prisoner came home—he could not get in to have his supper and go to bed—when Simmonds and his wife had a few words, the prisoner said, "You have been taking your pleasure all day, I will sit down and take mine, I will sit down till eleven o'clock and read the newspaper"—the mistress caught him, and gave him a shove—there were blows—the landlord got the handle of the broom and began cutting away at this man—he sung out "Police!"—I said, "I will go seek for one"—I went and could not see one—I staid out all night.

252.
RICHARD DAY
, for obtaining, by false pretences, 50 earthenware pipes, value 5l. 12s. 6d. the goods of
Henry Doulton and another.

HENRY DOULTON. I am partner with my father, we are potters, at High-street, Lambeth. In consequence of a communication, in August, I went to Victoria-road—the prisoner and Marson, who was convicted last Sessions, came there soon after—Marson said he required 600 pipes, the value of which was about 70l. for a sewer he was about to build—(there was a sewer being built)—he introduced me to the prisoner, as the ground-landlord of the pro
perty through which the sewer was to pass—he had said in the counting-house that the ground-landlord would be there; and when I got there, he said, "This is Mr. Day"—Marson walked a little way, and took me to another part, and then we returned to Day—we went into the Builders' Arms, and there Day gave me a written guarantee—it was handed to Jury on the trial of Marson, and I never saw it again.
MR. COOPER. Q. Was it produced by yourself, or the attorney? A. by me—I have not made inquiries here for it—I am quite certain as to the words of it.

MR. O'BRIEN. Q. He said the prisoner was the ground-landlord? A. Yes—the prisoner represented himself as the ground-landlord—Marson said, "Mr. Day, some gentlemen have been here to inquire the rent of your land, and I named a sum"—Day said that was quite right—Day was repeatedly referred to as the owner of the land—Day told me Marson was a very respectable man, he had known him a long while—he asked Marson how many pipes he would want—he said about 600—Day said, "Then, Mr. Doulton, you will send some over in the morning"—I sent one load next morning, it was the 24th or 25th Aug., by Stimpson, to the amount of 5l. 12s. 6d.—in conse
quence of what Stimpson said, I did not send any more—I wrote to Day—he had given me his address, "Richard Day, Esq., Eltham"—he replied by a letter, which I have here, in answer to mine—(read—"Eltham, 6th Sept. Gentlemen—I did not know the pipes were delivered; but I shall see Mr. Marson on the subject, when he will write you, and make a settlement when the contract is completed")—I have not received any money for the pipes I sent—I am not prepared to state that I should not have parted with the pipes, through Day had not guaranteed it.

Cross-examined by MR. COOPER. Q. Had you known Marson before? A. No—he was the principal speaker—he met me there alone—I think it is very likely. considering the circumstances, knowing that it was done under the Kennington Union, that I should have sent the materials, supposing Day had taken no part; but the guarantee was an additional security—in the conversation in the Builders' Arms, Marson said, "Mr. Day, some persons have been here inquiring the value of your land, what you let it at per house," referring to this very land—be said, "About your land here"—I cannot swear that the word "here" was used, but he referred to that land—I have heard that Day has banked, but rather disreputably—this letter is my writing (looking at one)—in this I applied to Day for the money—I know that he lived at Elt✗—the solicitor who sits by you, called once on me—I did not on that occasion agree to wait for the money—I said I had been out of town, or I should have prosecuted Day before—-the solicitor said the money would be paid very likely that day—I said I would not wait longer than that day.

ROBERT STIMPSON. I am carman to Mr. Doulton. On 26th Aug. I car
ried a load of fifty pipes from my master's to Victoria-road—I saw a sewer going on—I asked for Mr. Marson—he was not there—I went further, and inquired, but he was not there—I brought the pipes back to Victoria-road—I saw Mr. Marson there—he said to me, "Where have you been? you have been to the wrong place"—I said, "No"—I delivered the pipes at Victoria-road—Marson received them, and signed my bill, which was handed up here last Session—I heard something, and I communicated it to my master.
Cross-examined. Q. Were there men working there? A. Yes, at the sewer in Victoria-road, and the other sewer too.

ROBERT COCKBURN. I am a stone-mason, at Marlborough-road, Chelsea. On 26th or 27th Aug. I was asked if I knew any one who would by some pipes—I took fifty pipes from Victoria-road, where they were making a drain, to Mr. Thirst, in Cadogan-street, Chelsea—4l. 19s. 6d. was paid for them—Marson got two men to help me load—I saw the prisoner about the 15th Sept., I think—I told him I had heard that he and Marson had received some pipes under false pretences at a potter's some where at Lambeth, and I in
tended to go on to Marson and ascertain what it was—he said, "If you go there you will transport me, and think of my wife and child, what are they to do?"—I said, "You did not think of me"—I went on to Marson's, found Mr. Doulton, and went there.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you known Marson before? A. Yes, he was a joiner and builder—I had known Day a few months—Marson told me Day was an independent gentleman, living at Eltham—he brought him to my house, and said, "This is the gentleman that is going to advance me some money towards building"—when I spoke to Mr. Day, he did not say I was wrong—he flew in a passion, and said, "If you go there you will transport me"—I did not speak to policeman—I went to Mr. Doulton's—he said he was busy, and could, not attend to it; when he could he would send me a letter and let me know.
MR. O'BRIEN. Q. When did Marson bring Day to you? A. About June of July.

EDWARD THIRST. I am a builder. On 27th Aug. I bought fifty drain
pipes of Marson for 4l. 19s. 6d.—Mr. Doulton saw them two or three days afterwards, and owned them.

HENRY DOULTON
re-examined. I saw the pipes at Mr. Thirst's—they were what were sent to Marson.
COURT. Q. How came you to part with your pipes? A. Marson and day
being together, and Marson saying Day was the ground-landlord, and Marson stating in his presence that he was building a sewer, and had the contract for it.

SAMUEL WILLIAMS. I am a carman and a contractor—my brother and myself were contractors for that sewer that was building in Victoria-road, Kensington—I know Marson—he had nothing to do with building the sewer—we took the ground of Mr. Vallotton.
THEODGRE JAMES VALLOTTON. I live at 2, Hyde-park—my father is the ground-landlord of the ground on which this sewer was built in Victoria-road—I do not know Day—he has nothing to do with that land.
Cross-examined. Q. Does not Mr. Barry claim that land? A. I do not know—he claims all Kensington—the land on which the palace is built he claims.

CHARLES BURGESS GOFF (police-sergeant, L 8.) I took the prisoner in White Hart-court, Drury-lane—I passed him first, and from the description I had I believed him to be the man—I turned and said, "Good morning, Mr. Day"—he said, "Good morning"—I said I wanted him for being concerned with Marson in obtaining pipes from Mr. Doulton—he said, "You must have been planted on me"—he wanted to go to his solicitor—I took him to the station, and found on him this letter—(produced.)
(This letter was signed Richard Day, but bore no direction; it contained allusions to Marson, and mentioned his being in Horsemonger-lane gaol.)
Q. Day gave you his address? A. Yes—I went to Eltham for him, and found he had lived at a shoe-maker's shop there—I found a banker's receipt, which I produce.

GUILTY.—
Confined Six Months.

253.
JOHN BRIAN
, stealing 7lbs. weight of lead, value 15d. the goods of
Thomas Henry Maudsley and others, his masters; and
WILLIAM TAYLOR
, feloniously receiving the same; to which

BRIAN pleaded
GUILTY.

JAMES SHERIFF. I am foreman to Thomas Henry Maudsley and others, engineers—Brian was in their employ. In consequence of suspicion I watched him on Thursday, at dinner time, to Taylor's, a marine-store dealer's shop in the Upper Marsh, Lambeth—I saw him take something from his person, which was put into a scale, weighed, and then thrown under the counter by Mrs. Taylor—next day, at twelve o'clock, I watched him there again, and between twelve and half-past five, I got a constable to go with me—he went into the shop, and took possession of something—I immediately followed, and when I got in, Taylor said to the constable, "Do you call that lead?"—he said, "I do"—Taylor said, "It is zinc"—he was asked if he had bought any other articles of the man before—he said, no; he did not know that he had ever seen him in his shop before—Brian had taken the lead from his person—the policeman asked him where he got it—he made no reply—I believe it to be Mr. Thomas Henry Maudsley's and Joseph Field's.

JAMES CUDDY (policeman.) On Thursday evening, 28th Nov., I received information from Sheriff, watched Brian into Taylor's shop, and saw him take a piece of lead from under his jacket—Taylor's wife was inside the counter, and put the lead into the scale—he was passing in and out, and might not have seen it—he only said afterwards, "You don't call that lead; it is zinc."

254.
JOHN BRIAN was again indicted for
stealing 62lbs. weight of steel, value 10s. and 30 files, 10s. the goods of
Thomas Henry Maudsley and other, his master; and
WILLIAM TAYLOR
, feloniously receiving the same; to which BRIAN pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 50.—
Confined Six Months.

JAMES CUDDY (policeman.) I was watching Taylor's house—when I went in, I said, "Now, have you bought articles of any description of this man, prior to this?"—he said, "No, I have not; I don't know that I ever saw him before"—I said, "I am going to search the stop"—he said, "You can search it"—I searched under the counter, and under some rags I found 62lbs. of steel files—I asked if he wished to say who he bought them of—he said he could not tell, he bought them in what he called dribs and drabs, but he could not tell of whom—I took him in charge, and went before a Magi
strate with Brian next day—he acknowledged taking the greater part of them to Taylor's shop—Taylor said, "Yes, I bought them, a little at a time, of this man, he told me he had been employed where there had been a fire, and had picked them up in the ruins."
JAMES SHERIFF. I have examined the files found at Taylor's, and believe them to be Messrs. Maudsley's and Field's.
JOHN BOND. I was employed at Messrs. Maudsley's, and have examined the files—I used one of them on 27th Oct., and know it particularly.

JOHN LONGLAND. I am employed at Messrs. Maudsley's—I have used one of the files produced—each man puts a different mark on his files to dis
tinguish them.
JAMES PIRIE. I am an engineer, at Maudsley and Co.'s—I know one of these files, and am quite sure it is Messrs. Maudsley's.
Taylor's Defence. I did not know the files were stolen; I have bad eyes, and did not see that they were new. I asked where he got them, he said he found them among some rubbish.

JAMES CUDDY
re-examined. The files are not new—I asked Taylor if he made an entry of them—he said he kept no books, he did not buy anything which required an entry—he produced two loose leaves, the last entry on which was two years ago.
(Taylor received a good character.)

p.rs: GUILTY.* Aged 73.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.

div1.p:
255.
THOMAS YATES
, feloniously receiving 2 pairs of boots, and other articles, the goods of
Thomas Matthew Pocock, knowing them to have been stolen; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 25.—
Confined Four Months.

256.
FRANCIS LAPHAM
, stealing 1s. and 1d.
also, 2s. 3d.
also, 1s. 1d.
also, 2s. 3d. the moneys of
Robert Jones, his master, to all of which he pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 15.—
Confined Six Months.

257.
WILLIAM JOHNSTON
, stealing 1 metal cock, value 1s. and 1 copper ball, 1s., the goods of
Thomas Veness, fixed to a building; having been before convicted; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 16.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

258.
CLARA BOWKER
, stealing, at Clapham, 2 10l. bank-notes, the property of
Charles Rowley Kent, her master, in his dwelling-house.
MARY KENT. I am wife of Charles Rowley Kent—the prisoner was my charwoman—on 20th Oct. I received a sum of money from the Bank of

England—there were fourteen 10l. notes—I put them into a wardrobe in my bed-room, locked it, and put the key into my pocket—I went out next day between eleven and twelve—the prisoner was employed as charwoman that day—I returned between eight and nine at night, the prisoner was still there—about a fortnight afterwards I missed two notes from the wardrobe—I stopped them at the Bank next day—I afterwards accused the prisoner of taking them—she denied it strongly for a long time—I said, "It is no use your denying it, for no one was in the room but you, and I have traced one of the notes to Mr. Gainsford, in the Borough, and you had better own to it—I have since seen the two notes I missed.

Prisoner. She did not accuse me; a gentleman came to me and asked if I knew Mr. Gainsford, I said "Yes;" he asked if I had been to him last week or the week before; I said, "No;" he asked if I knew Mrs. Kent; I said, "Yes;" he said, "Have you heard she has lost two 10l. notes?" I said, "No;" he said, "You are suspected of taking them;" I said, "I did not;" he said, "I shall call a policeman, for you don't seem willing to confess, and I shall have a cab and take you;" he then said, he would come on Monday, and make me confess more than I was disposed to; I told him; I would confess at the Court; Mrs. King never mentioned the subject to me; the gentleman said, I should be made to confess at the Old Bailey; I denied ever having touched the money; Mrs. King said, "Why are you such a fool Clara, why don't you confess it, think of your children?" she said if I made 10l. good to her it should be all secret, and I should hear no more about it; I said, if I sold all I had in my house I would not take it.

SAMUEL VINCENT PRICE PHILLIPS. I am a clerk in the Bank of Eng
land—on 20th Oct. I paid Mrs. King fourteen 10l. notes, Nos. 10855 to 10868, dated 10th Sept. 1847—the Bank never issue two notes of the same number and date for the same amount—Mrs. Kent afterwards came for the numbers of the notes—two of them were 10867 and 10868—they were paid in through Barclay's Bank, on 27th Oct.

GEORGE ASHMORE. I am shopman to Messrs. Gainsford and Good, linendrapers, of High-street, Southwark—this note, No. 10867, has my writing on it—the prisoner paid it me on 25th Oct.—I was not certain before the Magistrate, but now I recollect the circumstance perfectly well, and what she bought—she is the person—she bought a black Ottoman scarf, price 2l. 10s., and a wool shawl, 17s. 6d., and I gave her 6l. 12s. 6d. change—the amount is put down—she gave her name Mrs. Anderson, Clapham-park, but did not give me the number—she appeared rather confused—I wrote her name on the note.
Prisoner. You could not swear to me at Kennington-lane. Witness. I recollected you after taxing my memory—I have served a good many people since—I did not Like to destroy you unless I was sure.

JOHN HAMBLIN (policeman, P 18.) I took the prisoner—she said some
thing to me in going to the station, and I took her to Messrs. Gainsford and Good's—she pointed out Mr. Ashmore, and he was taken before the Magis
trate—in consequence of what the prisoner said, I went to Mr. Bremming
ton's, at Clapham, and also to 6, Bedford-row, a respectable window's house, where I found this shawl and a scarf—(produced.)
MR. ASHMORE re-examined. This is the scarf I sold to the party who changed the 10l. note, and this shawl is of the same pattern and value, but our mark is taken off.

Prisoner's Defence. I gave 10s. for the shawl, at Mr. Gainsford's, in July; that was the last time I was there.
GUILTY. Aged 35.—
Confined One Year.

259.
CHARLES COOMBS
, feloniously forging and uttering a receipt for 4s. 2d.:
also a receipt for 2s. 10d.;
also a receipt for 3s. 10d. with intent to defraud
Thomas How; to all of which he pleaded

p.rs: GUILTY. He received a good character, and was recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.

div1.p:
260.
JAMES SULLIVAN and
JOHN DESMOND
, stealing 13 yards of rope, value 3s. the goods of
David Wheatcroft and another; and
ELIZA
BETH BAKER
, feloniously receiving the same; to which

SULLIVAN†* pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 14.—
Confined Six Months.

DESMOND† pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 14.—
Confined Three Months.

GEORGE BASS. I am carman to David Wheatcroft, who is in partnership with his son—they are carries. On the 22nd Nov. I stopped with my van in Stoney-lane, Tooley-street—I went into a public-house—I was called out in five minutes, and missed a rope—I went with Woods to Bermondsey-street—the male prisoners were standing in a shop at the counter, and Baker was behind the counter, with a handful of halfpence, as if she was going to pay them—she said something, but I had hold of them, and did not hear what it was—I did not see any rope then—I asked the boys if they had stolen the rope from my van—they said, "No"—I asked Baker what she was going to do with the halfpence—she said she was going to pay the boys for a little bit of old iron which they brought her—Woods said to the boys, "I can swear to you, I saw you take it"—Sullivan said, "You can't"—I said if they would give the rope up to me, I would let them go, and would not send for a police
man—I told Baker so a dozen times, and begged and prayed of them to give it up, but they would not, nor would Baker—I went for a policeman, who searched the place, and brought down this piece of rope (produced)—it be
longs to David Wheatcroft—Sullivan said, "I wish we had told you the truth; we did steal the rope, but the woman has not bought it yet"—Baker said that was the first time she had seen it.
Cross-examined by MR. WILDE. Q. How many sons are in partnership with Mr. Wheatcroft? A. Only one—I inquired of the head collector.

CHARLES WOODS. I live at Simons' wharf, Stoney-lane. On the evening of 22nd Nov,. I was in Stoney-lane, and saw Desmond lift Sullivan up to the van—Sullivan untied the rope, put it under his coat, and they ran in the direc
tion of Bermondsey-street—I told Bass, and went with him to Bermondsey-street, and pointed out the boys in a marine-store shop—I saw Baker with a handful of halfpence—she said, "9d., that is right"—I asked her whether she had seen a piece of rope—she said she had not all the day—she put the halfpence away again in the back-room—I remained till the policeman came,

EVEN JONES (policeman, M 250.) On the afternoon of the 22nd, I was called into Bermondsey-street by Woods, and found Bass with one hand on each of the boys—he gave them in charge—Baker was behind the counter—I asked her where the rope was—she said she had not seen any rope all day, but that they brought a bit of iron there—she said I might search—I com
menced doing so—she immediately ran into a back room, communicated with a female, and came back to the shop—I asked what was doing in that back room—she said, "Nothing"—the other female went up stairs—I went up in about five minutes, and saw her coming out of a room which was covered with rags—I searched, and found two or three pieces of rope—I brought them down, but Bass could not identify them—I afterwards found this piece under

other ropes, brought it down, he looked at both ends, and said, "That is my rope; I can swear to it"—Desmond said, "I wish I had told you the truth at first"—I said, "Well, mistress, you hear what he confesses"—she said, "Whatever I did, I have not bought it."
Cross-examined. Q. Did you see any iron about the place? A. No.

BAKER—
GUILTY. Aged 66.—
Confined Six Months.

261.
THOMAS NEWMAN
, stealing 22lbs. 15 oz. of copper, value 16s., the property of
Thomas Henry Maudsley and other, his masters.

WILLIAM DYKE. The prisoner was an engine-driver at Messrs. Maudaleys'—I was in their employ—on 4th Nov., in consequence of missing copper and brass, I watched the prisoner, and saw him look up to the top of the engine—I afterwards saw him on the top of the engine, pulling something about like—I watched till he went to tea, then went on the top of the engine, and found three bars of copper; I left it there—he came back, and went to work till the men left—he then set to to clean the engine—he put the lights very low, then reached the bars of copper down, tied them with some strings to his pockets, and then went and washed himself—I saw him leave, followed, and never lost sight of him, not half a second—I walked up and asked him to have some
thing to drink, as I could see no policeman—I asked a labourer to have some
thing to drink, and told him to fetch a policeman—the prisoner heard me say so—I said I was going to gave him into custody—he said, "For God's sake do not, for the sake of my wife and family; I have got a lot of copper upon me"—I said, "I know you have"—I gave him in charge—this is the same sort of cooper as was on Messrs. Maudsley's premises (produced)—we have it in large quantities—we should not miss 100 pieces—six pieces were found on the prisoner, tied with string—they are eight or ten feet long, but the pri
soner had cut them to carry them away.
JAMES SHERIFF. I am in the service of Messrs. Maudsley—this copper is worth 16s. or 1l.—it is the same as we have on our premises.
DAVID PEGRAM (policeman.) The prisoner was given in my charge—I searched him, and found six large pieces of copper on him.

GUILTY. Aged 25.—
Confined Twelve Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

262.
WILLIAM WARD
, stealing 4 keys, value 1s. 1 purse, 1s. 1 10l. note, and 3 sovereigns; the property of
George Redpath, from the person of
Ann Redpath; having been before convicted; and
THOMAS SMITH
, feloniously receiving one sovereign, part of the same; to which

WARD pleaded
GUILTY.—
Transported for Seven Years.

ANN REDPATH. My husband's name is George. On 22nd Oct. I was in the Borough—I had a bunch of keys, and a purse, with a 10l. note and three sovereigns and some silver in it—I did not see anything—somebody spoke to me—I felt in my pocket and missed my money, and when I got home I missed my keys.

WILLIAM PARKER. I am a coach-trimmer in the Dover-road. I saw the pri
soner pass close to Mrs. Redpath's side, and put his hand into her right-hand pocket—she walked on, and did not observe she was robbed—the prisoner was joined by two others—I told the lady—she waited a little time at my house—I got Burton, and we went in search of the prisoners—I pointed Ward out, and he was taken in charge—Smith followed—Ward put his hand in his

pocket and gave him something—they both got away—Smith was followed by the policeman, and taken—he gave the policeman a sovereign, which he said the other man had given him—he was taken to the station.
ELIZABETH PARKER. I am the wife of last witness. I was standing at my window and saw Ward commit the robbery.

JAMES BURTON (policeman.) I was on duty on 22nd Oct. in the Old Kent-road, and saw Ward and others in Kent-street—shortly after, I met Parker—he gave me information, and I went after Ward and took him—as we went along, Smith joined us—I saw nothing, as several of their companions were round me—I received information, and called to Smith—he ran away—I said to Ward, "You are well aware I know you"—I ran after Smith and overtook him—he took out a sovereign and said, "That is what the man gave me"—the Magistrate desired me to say that Smith was allowed to go upon his own recognizance—he has appeared here to-day.

Smith's Defence. I was not at the place when the robbery was commit
ted, and know no more about it than a child. SMITH—
NOT GUILTY.

263.
JOHN MANGAN
, stealing 6 shillings and 4 sixpences, the moneys of
John Bone, from his person.

JOHN BONE. I am potman at the Prince of Wales, in Brixton. On 22nd Nov., I went with a female friend in a cab to White Hart Inn, in the Borough—the prisoner asked me to change my cab, and I got into his—I had 11s. in my pocket, all but three farthing—he agreed to take me to Brixton for 2s.—he said be would save the gate, and go round by the Wellington; but he weat through, and insisted on my paying the toll—when we got through ken
nington-gate, he came into the cab and dabed against me, shoving me from one side to the other—I asked what he meant by it—he left a boy on the box to drive, and came inside—I missed my money—I spoke to him about it—he denied it, and punched my head—I said I would give him in charge, and told him to drive to the station, but he stopped on the way—I said I would go—we went there, and he denied it—he was searched, and 13s. 8d. was found on him—no one had been near me but him—I had been half asleep and half awake—I did not ask him to go in the cab with me—I asked what business he had there.
Prisoner. You got out; I demanded 8d. for my fare, which you would not give me. Witness. It is not true—I did not get out.
WILLIAM JOHN GIFFORD (policeman.) I was at the station—the prisoner and Bone came there together.
Prisoner. Q. Did not I drive him to the station? A. Yes—you denied the charge.

GEORGE FITZGERALD. I live in Redcross-court, Borough. I am out of employment—I worked for Mr. Cullum, driving a horse and cart—I cleaned horses in his stable—I know the prisoner—on 22nd Nov. I was with him—I never drove his cab—he never went into the cab until Bone got to his jour
ney's end, and then he woke him up—it was about two o'clock in the morn
ing—I went that distance with him, as I had nothing to do—on my oath did not drive the cab on that or any other occasion—I do know his horse—the road was heavy—the prisoner let his horse walk, because he sweated.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, DECEMBER 13TH, 1847.
